Donec vehicula augue eu neque. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas. Mauris ut leo. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Figure 4.3: Schematic representation of the examples presented in Section 4.4.2. the vicinity of a region X . We say that an interaction F is X -anchored if Z SX =FS =0 and it will be convenient to have an associated norm ||F ||X,f = ||F ||f { F is X -anchored otherwise (4.5.1) If F is X-anchored for a finite X, then F determines in a natural way an element (F) of A, see Section 4.2.2, where it was used primarily to define the almost local algebra Aal. Anchored TDIs are defined in a similar fashion, with norm |||H |||X,f = sups[0,1] ||H(s)||X,f. We note that if X is a finite set and |||H|||X,f < , the almost local evolution is generated by a time-dependent family of self-adjoint elements of A, namely (H(s)), see Lemma 4.5.5. 4.5.2 Manipulating interactions We need some results about manipulating interactions and TDIs. We first introduce these manipulations algebraically and then we state most of the relevant bounds. Commutators Given interactions H,H we define the commutator interaction ([H,H])S = [HS1,HS2] S1,S2:S1S2=S S1S2 The same symbol was already used in Section 4.2.2 to denote the action of an interaction on Aal. These two usages are consistent with each other: If H is anchored in a finite set, then (H) Aal. In particular, [H,(H)] is well defined and([H,H]) = [H,(H)]. If also H is anchored in a finite set, then the latter expression equals [(H),(H)] with [,] the standard commutator on A. Derivations The action of an interaction H on Aal by [H, ] is an (unbounded) derivation. It is the derivation, rather then the interaction itself, that determines the almost local evolution H. One should notice that distinct H H can give rise to the same derivation, which complicates some of our calculations. Therefore, we introduce the relation to indicate equality of derivations; H H iff. [H, A] = [H, A] A Aal Weak sums Given a family of interactions H(n) indexed by n Z, we define the weak sum n H(n) by ( H(n))S = HS(n), n n provided the right-hand side is absolutely norm-convergent for every S. 4.5.3 Automorphisms Since we consider spin chain algebras A where for every finite S, AS is finite- dimensional, there is a well-defined tracial state on A. For a region X, we write Xc : A A for the corresponding conditional expectation 1AX Xc. This linear map is contracting: ||Xc[A]|| ||A||. We define a canonical decomposition of observables A A into finitely suppported terms centered at a given site j Z, A = kN Aj,k, defined by Aj,k = {Bkc(j)[A] Bkc1 (j)[A] k > 0 B0c(j)[A] k = 0 , (4.5.2) where we used the balls Bk(j) = {dist(,j) k}. Given an interaction F that is X-anchored and a -automorphism , we define [F] by ([F ])Bk(j) = 1 ( [FS ])j,k (4.5.3) |X S| S:SX for any k and j X. For S that are not of the form Bk(j) with j X, we set ([F])S = 0. This definition satisfies the following constraint on the N associated derivations. [[F ], ] = [F, ] 1 (4.5.4) and the integrated version for a TDI H follows from the definition (4.2.1) [H] = H 1 (4.5.5) where [H](s) = [H(s)]. However, the above definition of [F] is of course not the unique definition satisfying these properties. For example, if F is X-anchored, then it is also X-anchored, whenever X X. The transformed interaction resulting from the definition (4.5.3) does in general change upon replacing X by X, whereas the associated derivations are equal. Let us illustrate a particular and relevant consequence of this. Let H be an almost local evolution and F an interaction, so that the family H(s)[F] is defined by (4.5.3) for every s [0, 1]. Then in general the Heisenberg-like evolution equation H (s)[F ] F = i 0s du H (u){[H (u), F ]} is not correct as an equation between interactions, but the equality does hold on the level of derivations, i.e. we do have s H (s)[F ] F i du H (u){[H (u), F ]} 0 with introduced in Section 4.5.2. 4.5.4 Bounds on transformed interactions To state bounds on transformed interactions, we will need to adjust the functions f F as we go along. It would be too cumbersome to define each time explicity the adjusted function, and therefore we introduce the following generic notion: Definition 4.5.1. We say that f is affiliated to f (and depends on some parameter C) if i. Both f, f are elements of F and f depends only on f (and on the the parameter C). ii. If f(r) Cecr for some < 1 and c,C > 0, then f(r) Cecr for some C,c > 0. We will also use repeatedly that max(f1, f2) F if f1, f2 F. Lemma 4.5.2. Let F, Fn, n Z be interactions and H a TDI. Let X, Xn be regions (possibly infinite) and let f, f1, f2 be elements of F. i. If X1 X2 = , then ||[F1, F2]|| f(dist(X1, X2)||F1||X1,f1||F2||X2,f2, for f affiliated to f = max(f1, f2). ii. If X = X1 X2 is not empty, then ||[F1, F2]||X,f ||F1||X1,f1||F2||X2,f2, for f affiliated to f = max(f1, f2). iii. If all Xn are mutually disjoint, then || Fn||X,f sup ||F (n)||Xn,f , X = nXn n n for faffiliated to f. iv. Assume that |||H|||f1 CH for some CH < . Then ||H(s)[F]||X,f ||F||X,f2, s [0,1] for faffiliated to f = max(f1,f2) and depending on CH. Note that the upper bounds are trivial if the interactions are not anchored in the respective sets, see (4.5.1). Since the proofs rely on standard techniques, we refer to the similar statements in [44, 7] and their proofs, see also the proof of Lemma 4.5.5. Item iv is a consequence of the Lieb-Robinson bound. One of the main difference with the cited references is the use of slightly different norms, but they can be shown to be equivalent, see the appendix of [6]. 4.5.5 Inversion, time-reversal, and composition of almost local evolutions We will often need to invert, time-reverse, and compose almost local evolutions. For TDIs H, H1, H2, we set (H1)(s) = (H(s))1, (4.5.6) (H)(s) = H1(1) H(1 s), (4.5.7) (H2 H1 )(s) = H2 (s) H1 (s). (4.5.8) Lemma 4.5.3. The families of automorphisms defined in (4.5.7),(4.5.6) and (4.5.8), parametrized by s [0, 1] are almost local evolutions. More precisely: i. The TDI H(s)[H(s)] generates the inverse H1. ii. The TDI H(1 s) generates H, the time-reversal of H. iii. The TDI H1(s) + H11(s)[H2(s)] generates the composition H2 H1 Proof. The proposed families of interactions have a finite ||| |||f-norm for some f F by Lemma 4.5.2. They are strongly measurable: If H(s) is strongly measurable, it is the pointwise limit of a piecewise constant interaction; The definition (4.2.1) and the bounds of Lemma 4.5.2 further imply that H(s) can be approximated by a piecewise constant automorphism. The fact that they generate the given families of automorphisms follows from a direct computation. If () is a loop generated by a TDI H, then the time-reversal H generates the time-reversed loop () that was defined in Section 4.3.2. Indeed, using that and have the same basepoint (0), we verify (0)H(s) = (0)H1(1)H(1s) = (0)H(1s) = (1s) = (s). We now introduce the notion of a cocyle, associated to an almost local evolution. The cocycle H (s, u), with u s, is defined as H (s, u) = H1(u) H (s) (4.5.9) so that in particular H (s) = H (s, 0). It corresponds to the evolution from time u to time s. The cocyle satisfies the cocyle equation H(s, u) = H(s, u) H(s, s). (4.5.10) and the evolution equation H(s,u)[A]=A+i dsH(s,u){[H(s),A]}. s u In particular, H (s, u) satisfies the same bound as H (s) in Lemma 4.5.2(iv). Now we can then state the Duhamel principle: H2(s)H1(s)=i H2(u){[H2(u)H1(u),H1(s,u){}]}du (4.5.11) s 0 which is established in the usual way from the Heisenberg equation (4.2.1). Lemma 4.5.4. If H1, H2 are TDIs, then i. The TDI H1(s)[H2(s) H1(s)] generates the almost local evolution H2 H11. ii. The TDI H2(s) H1(s) + iH12(s)[ s H2(u){[H2(u) H1(u), H1(s, u){H1(s)}]}du ] 0 (4.5.12) generates the almost local evolution H11 H2 . Proof. Both claims follow by applying Lemma 4.5.3. For the second claim, one uses the Duhamel principle applied to interactions, more concretely, H2 (s)[H (s)] H (s)[H (s)] i s 0 H2 (u){[H2 (u) H (u), H (s, u){H (s)}]}du. (4.5.13) 4.5.6 Applications of the Duhamel principle We establish a few consequences of the bounds in the previous sections. Even though they are straightforward, they will be used so often that it is worthwile to highlight them. First of all, we introduce the L1 norm on TDIs, given by |||H |||(X1,)f 1 := ds||H (s)||X,f 0 Of, course, we always have |||H|||(X1,)f |||H|||X,f , but some bounds are stated more naturally in terms of the L1-norm. Lemma 4.5.5. Let X, Y be intervals or complements thereof and let A AY . i. If F is an interaction anchored in X , then ||[F, A]|| ||A||||F ||X,f f(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X Y |) (4.5.14) with f affiliated to f . ii. Let H1, H2 be TDIs satisfying |||H1|||f CH, |||H2|||f CH for some constant CH. If H1 H2 is anchored in X, then ||H1 (s)[A] H2 (s)[A]|| ||A|||||H1 H2|||(X1,)f f(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X Y |) (4.5.15) with f affiliated to f and depending on CH . Note that the intervals are possibly infinite. Also, the right hand side of (4.5.14) is allowed to be infinite, but if it is finite then [F, A] is a well-defined element of A. Proof. We write [F, A] = [FS , A]. SY ,SX Hence, ||[F, A]|| 2||FS||||A|| 2||A|| f(1 + dist(y, X))||F||X,f yY Sy,SX yY where we used the definition of the f -norm and the fact that f is non-increasing. The bound f (1 + dist(y, X)) f(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X Y |) now holds in the particulyarYcase of intervals. For ii) we use Duhamels formula (4.5.11) to get H1 (s)[A] H2 (s)[A] = i s du H1 (u) H2 (s, u){[H12(s, u){H1(s) H2(s)}, A]} 0 (4.5.16) bounded by an expression depending on CH. Therefore, we invoke Lemma 4.5.2 By the results above, H12(s,u) is generated by a TDI whose norm is upper item iv) to get ||H12(s, u){H1(s) H2(s)}||X,f ||H1(s) H2(s)||X,f uniformly in u, s 1. Using now item i) above, he argument of {} in (4.5.16) is in norm bounded by ||H1(s) H2(s)||X,f ||A||f(1 + dist(X, Y ))(1 + |X Y |), which proves the claim since H1 (u) and H2 (s, u) preserve the norm. The next lemma elaborates on the situation when a TDI K is anchored in a set X. If X is finite, then K(s) is an inner automorphism, i.e. we retrieve the formulas familiar from finite quantum systems: K (s)[A] = Ad(V (s))[A] (4.5.17) with V (s) A a unitary family that solves V(s)=1+i duV(u)(K(u)). s 0 Lemma 4.5.6. Let H be a TDI and B a TDI anchored in X, i. There are TDIs K, K anchored in X such that H+B = H K = K H. If H, B are G-invariant, then so are K, K. ii. Let be a pure state andlet X be finite. Then the states H+B and H are mutually normal. If and H, B are G-invariant, then the relative charge of H+B and H is zero. Proof. Item i). We use Lemma 4.5.3 and Lemma 4.5.4 to derive expressions for K, K. Then we use Lemma 4.5.2 to pass the property of being anchored in X from B to K, K. Item ii). By i) and the fact that K is anchored on a finite set, the remark preceding the lemma ensures that there is a unitary V A such that = Ad(V ). In particular they are normal with respect to each other. If V is G-invariant, then they have zero relative charge. 4.5.7 Concatenation of almost local evolutions First, we remark that one can often construct almost local evolutions by time- rescaling. This is used so often that we put it in a lemma. Lemma 4.5.7. Let H be a TDI and let j : [0,1] [0,1] be a piecewise smooth function, with |djd(ss)| Cj, except for a finite set of times s. Then H1(j(0))H(j()) is an almost local evolution. Proof. We set K = djd(ss) H (s), except for the finite set of times where the bound |djd(ss)| Cj does not hold, where we set K(s) = 0. We see that |||K|||f Cj|||H|||f for any f F so that the TDI satisfies the necessary bound. The fact that it generates the family H1(j(0)) H(j()) follows from direct computation. For almost local evolutions , , we define the concatenated evolution by ( )(s) = {((21s)) (2s 1) 0 s <1/21/2 s < 1 (4.5.18) The family of automorphisms ( )(s) is again an almost local evolution by Lemma 4.5.3. We also note the relation to the concatenation of loops defined in (4.3.3): If , are loops with common basepoint and generated by , , then is a loop with the same basepoint and generated by . We will now state that composition of almost local evolutions is, in a certain sense, homotopic, to concatenation of almost local evolutions. Definition 4.5.8. A family (s, ) ()(s) is a G-homotopy of almost local evolutions if (0)() ()(s) = (0)(s) (s)(), for any s, [0, 1] with (), (s), for each , s, generated by G-invariant TDIs H, Fs satisfying the uniform boundedness property (4.3.2) and such that (0)() = (1)() = Id (4.5.19) Before, the homotopy was defined as a property of a function (s, ) (s) of states. The connection with the above definition is the following: If (s, ) ()(s) is a homotopy of almost local evolutions, then (s, ) ()(s) is a homotopy, for any choice of state . Note that this is a homotopy with fixed basespoint in the sense that the basepoint of the interpolating loops ()() is for all [0, 1]. To complete the vocabulary, two almost local evolutions (0), (1) are called G-homotopic if there exists a G-homotopy () reducing to (0) for = 0 and to (1) for = 1. Finally, note that the condition (4.5.19) is the analogue of the restriction to loops in Section 4.3.2. If we omit this condition, any local evolution would be homotopic to identity. The main reason to consider homotopy of almost local evolutions, is given by the following lemma. Lemma 4.5.9. i. Let H be a G-invariant TDI and let j : [0, 1] [0, 1] be a piecewise smooth function, whose derivative is bounded (except for a finite set), and such that j(0) = 0 and j(1) = 1. Then H() and H(j()) are G-homotopic. ii. Let H1, H2 be two G-invariant TDIs. Then H2 H1 is G-homotopic to H2H1. Proof. Item i) We consider the family (s) = (k(s, )), k(s, ) = (1 )s + j(s) For any s, the function k(s,) satisfies the conditions of Lemma 4.5.7 and hence it yields the required almost local evolution (s)() = 1(s)(k(s,)). The condition (4.5.19) follows from the fact that j(0) = 0 and j(1) = 1. Item ii) For simplicity, let us denote (s) = H1(s) and (s) = H2(s). We will construct a family (s) interpolating between and as ranges between 0 and 1. Let d() = 12 (1 + , 1 ) [0, 1]2, [0, 1]. Let j() : [0, 1] [0, 1]2 : s j()(s) = (j1(s), j2()(s)) be the continuous and piecewise smooth map defined by j()(s) = {2ds(d)(+) 2(s 12 )((1, 1) d()) s 1/2 s > 1/2 . We note that j(0)(s) = (s, s), j(1)(s) = {(2s, 0) s 1/2 (1, 2s 1) s > 1/2 (4.5.20) Then we define the family of automorphisms ()(s) = (j1()(s)) (j2()(s)), [0, 1]. We verify i. ()(0) = Id and ()(1) = (1) (1) because j()(0) = (0, 0), j()(1) = (1, 1). ii. (0)(s) = ( )(s). iii. (1)(s) = ( )(s). iv. For each , () is an almost local evolution. v. ()(s) = (0)(s) (s)(), with (s)() = (s)1 (s)1 (j1()(s)) (j2()(s)) vi. For each s, (s) is an almost local evolution. vii. (0)() = (1)() = Id, so item (v) means that (s, ) ()(s) is a homotopy. Item (iiii) and (vii) are immediate consequences of the definition, using (4.5.20). To check (iv), we use Lemma 4.5.7 to conclude that both (j1()()) and (j2()()) are almost local evolutions and so is their composition by Lemma 4.5.3. Item (v) follows from the definition of ()(s) and (ii). Item (vi) follows from Lemma 4.5.7 upon noting that j()(s) has uniformly bounded derivatives and j(0)(s) = (s, s). 4.6 Hilbert space theory for states equivalent to a product state Although most of our reasoning stays on the level of the spin chain algebra A, some steps are easier taken within the GNS representation. In this section, we establish the tools that we will need from Hilbert space theory. 4.6.1 GNS construction We will make use of the GNS representation of state on A, see [12]. As before, we denote the GNS triple associated to by (H, , ) (Hilbert space H, vector H, -representation : A B(H)), such that (A) = , [A], for any A A. From the purity of , it follows that (A) = C1 and hence the von Neumann algebra (A) equals the full algebra B(H). The following lemma, already used in Section 4.3.1, verifies that we are in the setting outlined in Section 4.3.1. HILBERT SPACE THEORY FOR STATES EQUIVALENT TO A PRODUCT STATE Lemma 4.6.1. If is G-invariant, then there is a unique strongly continuous unitary representation G U(H) : g U(g), such that U(g) = and (g) = Ad(U(g)) (4.6.1) Proof. By the uniqueness of the GNS representation, up to unitary equivalence, it follows that for each g G there is a unique unitary U(g) such that U(g) = and such that (4.6.1) holds. From (A) = C1, it also follows that U(g)U(g)U1(gg) is a multiple of identity and by the invariance of , it follows that this multiple of identity is identity. This yields that g U(g) is a genuine representation. To get the strong continuity of g U(g), it suffices to get continuity of g U(g) for D with D H dense. We choose D = {(A),A A} and we note that g U(g)(A) = U(g)(A)U(g) = ((g)[A]) is continuous by the strong continuity of g (g) and the continuity of . Two pure states , are said to be mutually normal5 iff. is represented as a pure density matrix in the GNS representation of : (A) = TrH((A)). It then follows that the same holds with the roles of , reversed. 4.6.2 GNS representation of a product We construct the GNS representation of a pure, G-invariant product state in a pedagogical way to render the objects that follow more tangible. (To avoid any possible confusion, we are going to construct a representation that is unitarily algebra of ni ni complex matrices, that we write as Ai = B(Cni ) For every i, equivalent to the canonical GNS representation.) Recall that Ai is a matrix we choose an orthonormal basis of ni labelled by = 0, . . . , ni 1 such that C (A) = 0|A|0, A Ai. The state corresponds hence intuitively to the -a priori ill-defined- vector . . . |0i1 |0i |0i+1 . . . (4.6.2) The representation Hilbert space H is chosen as H := l2(MZ) 5The term equivalent is used more often in the literature, but we avoid this term since it has already another natural meaning within this paper. However, in the zero-dimensional case, the two notions actually coincide. where MX , for X Z, is the space of sequences m : X {0, 1, 2 . . .} such that m(j) < nj and the set {j : m(j) 0} is finite. We write henceforth HX = 2(MX) and we note the tensor product structure H = HX HXc. We now define an isometry KS : jSCnj HS for finite S, by { KS(jS|mj)(m) = 1 0 m = m m m , m, m MS and we lift it to an isomorphism of C-algebras by setting S : AS B(HS) : A KSAKS1. Then the representation : A B(H) is fixed by the requirement that its restrictions AS : AS 1Sc B(HS)) 1HSc coincide with S, for finite S. We note that for finite S, S = |AS : (AS) B(HS) is an isomorphism, whereas for infinite X, (AX) is a strict subset of B(HX). In case X is afinite set S, we have equality (AS) = B(HS) and restricts to an isomorphism of C-algebras between AS and B(HS). In that case, the dual space of functionals on AS is isomorphic to the trace-class operators on HS, equipped with the trace norm || ||1. The state is now represented by the vector = m0, H with m0(j) = 0 for all j; (A) = , [A] and we see that indeed corresponds to the heuristic (4.6.2), and it factors as = X Xc. We denote by X (and again = ) the orthogonal projection on the range of X and we abuse notation by also writing X to Z denote X 1Xc. We now state a relevant condition for a pure state to be normal with respect to the product state . We fix intervals in centered on the sites {0, 1}; Z I1 = , Ir = [2 r, r 1], r > 1. (4.6.3) Then Lemma 4.6.2. Let , be a pure states on A and let be a product. If ||( )Irc || 0 as r , then is normal w.r.t. . Proof. Let Ir be the density matrix on the finite-dimensional Hilbert space HIr representing the state Ir . We consider the sequence (indexed by r) Ir Irc (4.6.4) and we prove now that this sequence is a Cauchy sequence in trace-norm || ||1. Let us denote (r) = ||( )Irc|| and abbreviate r = Ir, r,r = Ir\Ir for r < r and let Trr be the trace on HIr. Then ||r Irc r Irc||1 = ||r r r,r||1 (4.6.5) ||r r,rrr,r||1 + ||r,rrr,r r r,r||1. (4.6.6) To bound the first term in (4.6.6), we compute, for A B(Hr), ||r r,r r r,r ||1 = sup | Trr [(r,r r r,r r )A]| (4.6.7) AB(Hr ),||A||1 3 Trr [r (1 r,r )] sup Trr [r AA] AB(Hr ),||A||1 (4.6.8) 3 Trr[r(1 r,r)] 3 (r) (4.6.9) where we used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the fact that Trr [r (1 r,r )] = (1 r,r ) = ( )(1 r,r ). To bound the second term in (4.6.6), we observe that r,r acts as a rank-1 projector on HIr \Ir , hence r,r r r,r is equal to cr r,r with c 0. Since c = Trr [r,r r r,r ] 1 (r), the second term in (4.6.6) is bounded by (r). It follows that (4.6.4) is indeed a Cauchy sequence and it converges hence to a density matrix . Therefore, the normal states on A, induced by the density matrices (4.6.4) form a Cauchy sequence as well and they have a limit. The limit is necessarily equal to since is obviously a limit point (hence the unique limit point) in the weak-topology. We therefore conclude that is represented by . As remarked in Section 4.4.1, this lemma also follows from Corollary 2.6.11 in [12]. Unlike there, the proof given here yields quantitative bounds, whichThen, taking r in the proof of Lemma 4.6.2, we havewe collect now. We use the notations above, in particular (r) = ||( )Irc||. || Ir Irc||1 4(r), (4.6.10) || IrcIrc||1 3(r). We fix this state in what follows, and we consider a G-invariant TDI H that generates a loop H(), satisfying |||H|||f CH for some f F and some constant CH. As in Section 4.4.1, we cut the TDI by defining H to contain only the terms HS supported on the left, S 0, obtaining the pumped state = H(1). (4.6.13) We first establish that is normal w.r.t . Lemma 4.6.3. There is f affiliated to f and depending on CH such that ||( )Irc || f(r) (4.6.14) Therefore, as a consequence of Lemma 4.6.2, is normal w.r.t. Proof. Clearly, is a product = 0 1, and 1 = 1. It follows that ||( )Irc|| = ||( )<2r|| = sup |(A) (A)| AA<2r,||A||1 and we now estimate the last quantity: |(A) (A)| = |(H(A) H(A))| f(r)||A|| (4.6.15) where the equality follows because H () is a loop, and the inequality follows from Lemma 4.5.5 item ii), with the input that H H is anchored in { 1} and that all constants that appear can be bounded by functions of CH . Since is normal w.r.t. , and the G-action is implemented by a unitary representation, see Lemma 4.6.1, we can indeed define the index I(, H) introduced in Section 4.4.1. We will now derive some topological properties of the map H I(, H). Properties of the index map I(, ) We fix again the product state and its GNS triple. We also fix f F and a constant CH. We let S = S(CH, f, ) be the set of G-invariant TDIs such that i. |||H|||f CH ii. H() is a loop To any H S, we associate the pumped state = H(1) Let T1,(H) the set of pure G-invariant density matrices on H. In particular, , the density matrix representing the state on H, is in T1,(H). We then define the function : S T1,(H) : H Next, let g U(g) be the unique unitary representation on H given in Lemma 4.6.1. We set : T1,(H) H1(G) : () where () is the homomorphism G S1 defined by ei()(g) = Tr(U (g)) U (1) (4.6.16) Because of the specific choice of U(), we find that () = h/. We consider S, T1,(H), H1(G) with topologies induced by, respectively, the norm ||| |||(f1), the trace norm || ||1, and the metric d(h, h) = supgG |h(g) h(g)|S1. With these choices, the map is Lipschitz. Indeed, for any (1), (2) T1,(H), d(((1), (2) )) CS1 sup | Tr[(1)U (g)] Tr[(2)U (g)]| ||(1) (2)||1. gG with CS1 = sup(0,2] |ei||1| < . We now show Lemma 4.6.4. The maps : S T1(H) and I(, ) = : S H1(G) are uniformly continuous. Proof. We have already remarked that is Lipschitz, so both claims will be proven once we show that is uniformly continuous, which we do now. Consider H(1), H(2) S and let (j) = (H(j)). We have ||(1) (2)||1 ||(I1r) Irc (I2r) Irc||1 + ||(I1r) Irc (1)||1 + ||(I2r) Irc (2)||1 ||(I1r) (I2r)||1 + 8f(r) where we used the bound (4.6.10) with (r) = f(r), by Lemma 4.6.3. To bound the difference ||(I1r) (I2r)||1, we rewrite it as sup | (H(1))(1)[A] (H(2))(1)[A]| (4.6.17) AAIr,||A||1 which is bounded by f(1)|Ir||||H(1) H(2)|||(f1) by Lemma 4.5.5. We hence get ||(1) (2)||1 f(1)|Ir| |||H(1) H(2)|||(f1) + 8f(r) It it important to note that, since f is fixed, f can be fixed as well. Since f(r) 0 as r 0, we can now find a modulus of continuity for the function . Finally, we formulate a proposition that will be used crucially in the proof of homotopy invariance of the index map I(, ). Proposition 4.6.1. There is an > 0, such that, if |||H(1) H(2)|||(f1) for H(1), H(2) S, then I(, H(1)) = I(, H(2)). Proof. For a given h H1, the discreteness of H1 implies that there is an (h) > 0 such that d(h, h) (h) implies h = h. However, since the metricand one can choose uniformly on H1. The claim of the proposition follows on H1 is homogenous, namely d(h, h) = d(h h, 0), we find (h) = (0) then from the uniform continuity of the index map I (, ) on S , i.e. from Lemma 4.6.4. 4.6.4 Connecting states by adiabatic flow States that are mutually normal, can be connected via an almost local evolution whose generating TDI is anchored in a finite set. In other words, the almost local evolution consists of inner automorphisms. In this section, we establish this statement in a quantitative way, but restricted to the specific setting in which we will need it. The crucial Lemma 4.6.6 below is taken from [33]. Parallel transport for 0-dimensional systems We first exhibit how to connect states on 0-dimensional systems, i.e. states on B(H), with H a Hilbert space. We say that a bounded, measurable function [0, 1] s E(s) with E(s) = E(s) B(H) is a zero-dimensional TDI and we set |||E||| = sups[0,1] ||E(s)||. The evolution s E(s) is then defined as the family of automorphisms that is the unique solution to the equation E(s)=1+i duE(s){[E(u),]}. s 0 Lemma 4.6.5. Let , be pure normal states on B(H). Then there exist zero-dimensional TDI E, such that i. |||E||| < 8|| || ii. = E(1) iii. If both , are invariant under a G-action by automorphisms (s), and h/ = 0, then E can be chosen G-invariant as well. The proof of this lemma uses only basic linear algebra and we postpone it to Appendix A.1. Parallel transport for states normal to Let be a pure state normal w.r.t. the pure product state . Recall the definition of the intervals Ir in (4.6.3). Lemma 4.6.6. Let be a pure state and a pure product state, such that ||( )Irc || f (r), f F (4.6.18) Then there exist a TDI K such that i. |||K |||{0,1},f < 1 for f affiliated to f . ii. = K (1) iii. If both , are G-invariant, with zero relative charge h/ = 0, then K can be chosen G-invariant. Proof. By Lemma 4.6.2, is normal w.r.t. . Let be the density matrix on H representing . We set r = Tr[IrcIrcIrcIrc ] , provided Tr[Irc Irc ] 0 (4.6.19) By the bounds (4.6.11) and (4.6.12) with (r) = f(r) and the fact that f is non-increasing, there is a finite r0 > 0 such that for r r0, the denominator (4.6.19) is not zero. For 1 r r0, we set simply r = (which coincides with the definition (4.6.19) for r = 1). In any case, the densities r are of the form r Icr with r pure. We have ||r+1 r Ir+1\Ir||1 = ||r+1 r||1 ||r ||1 + ||r+1 ||1 4f(r) + 4f(r + 1) 8f(r) by (4.6.12) with (r) = f(r). We now apply Lemma 4.6.5 to obtain a zero-dimensional TDI Er() of operators on HIr+1 transporting r Ir+1 into r+1, satisfying the bound sup||Er(s)|| 8f(r) (4.6.20) s and we identify Er() with Er() 1Irc+1 so that Er() are viewed as operators on H transporting r into r+1. Since the restricted GNS representation |AX : AX B(HX) is bijective for X finite, we can define Kr(s) = 1(Er(s)) AIr+1 It remains to assemble this family of time-dependent operators into a single TDI. Let Tr [0, 1] be half-open intervals [t, t) of length (2/6)1 1/r2 such that min T1 = 0 and sup Tr = min Tr+1. Note that rTr = [0, 1). The bound |||K |||{0,1},f < 1 now follows from the bounds (4.6.20). The other claims simply carry over from Lemma 4.6.5. A LOOP WITH TRIVIAL INDEX AND PRODUCT BASEPOINT IS HOMOTOPIC TO A SHORT LOOP 87 4.7 A loop with trivial index and product basepoint is homotopic to a short loop In this section, we fix again a specific setup. We fix a G-invariant pure product state on a spin chain algebra, and a G-invariant TDI H such that H () is a loop whose index is trivial; I (, H ) = 0. We also fix an f F and a constant CH such that |||H|||f CH. The only aim of this is section is to prove that this loop is G-homotopic to an arbitrarily short loop, in the sense that the norm of the generator is arbitrarily small: Proposition 4.7.1. There exists G-invariant TDIs H(R), with R 2N such that () is a loop that is G-homotopic to H (), and such that H(R) Rlim |||H (R)|||f = 0. for f affiliated to f and depending on CH . The homotopy can be chosen to have fixed basepoint . Throughout the section, we keep the loop and its generating TDI H fixed, together with f F and CH . All constants C that appear can depend on CH and f . In particular, we write f for functions affiliated6 to f and depending on CH. Just like for constants C, we will use fas a generic notation, and its precise value can hence change from line to line. 4.7.1 Splitting of the loop at a single edge We say that a TDI F is split at an edge (j, j + 1) iff. min S j < max S s : FS (s) = 0. In such a case, we can write F = Fj + F>j where, obviously, Fj , F>j consist of terms FS with max S j and min S > j, respectively. The aim of this section is to modify the TDI H locally, H H + E(j), such that it is split at (j, j + 1) while still generating a loop with basepoint , see also Figure 4.4. We write H = Hj + H>j + Bj, where (Bj)S = (min S j < max S)HS 6As defined in Section 4.5.2 such that H Bj is split at (j, j + 1). Note that for j = 0, we previously used the notation H for H0. We recall that the pumped state H0(1) is assumed to have zero charge with respect to . The following lemma uses and strenghtens this statement. Lemma 4.7.1. Let = Hj(1), + = H>j(1) Then the states |j, +|>j have zero relative charge with respect to (in particular: are normal with respect to) |j, |>j, respectively. Proof. Since = |j |>j and + = |j +|>j, we have h(|j/|j) = h(/), h(+|>j/|>j) = h(+/) (4.7.1) fromitemiii)ofProposition4.3.1. Therefore,inwhatfollows,weabusenotation and we write ,+ also for |j,+|>j, as the potential for confusion is small. Then + = HBj(1) = H(1) L(1) = L(1) where, by Lemma 4.5.6, L is a G-invariant TDI anchored in {j, j + 1}. The last equality follows because H generates a loop. By invoking the last item of Lemma 4.5.6, we conclude that + has zero charge wrt. . Therefore, chosen as j = 0, then the state is precisely the pumped state defined in using (4.7.1) and Proposition 4.3.1, we have h/ + h+/ = 0. If the site j is Section (4.4.1). However, the TDIs H = H0 and Hj differ by an interaction anchored in a finite set, therefore the resulting states have equal charge, invoking again Lemma 4.5.6. Since we assumed that the loop generated by H has index zero, the claims follow. H (s): s=1 s = 3/4 s = 1/2 s = 1/4 j j +1 s = 0 H (s): H+E(j)(s): j j +1 H(s) + E(j)(s): Figure 4.4: The TDI H is modified locally around edge (j, j + 1) so that it is split at this edge. This means that H(s) is split for all s [0, 1]. Lemma 4.7.2. For any site j Z, there is a G-invariant TDI E(j) with |||E(j)|||{j,j+1},f C, such that H + E(j) is split at the edge (j, j + 1) and it generates a loop with basepoint . In particular the affiliated function f can be chosen independently of j. Proof. We fix j and we use again the notation , + as above. By the same analysis as the one in the proof of Lemma 4.6.3, we get that ||( )|jr2|| f(r), ||( +)|j+r|| f(r). We will use Lemma 4.6.6 to connect these states. Even though Lemma 4.6.6 is formulated for states on a spin chain algebra, i.e. referring to the graph A = AZ, with X = { j} and once with X = {> j}, to obtain TDIs K, K+, supportedit of course holds just as well for states on AX with X Z. We apply it onceon { j} and {> j}, and such that + = K(1), K = K + K+, |||K|||{j,j+1},f 1, with f chosen independently of j. Hence we have now obtained that the path of states HBj K1() is aloop with basepoint and it is factorized between { j} and {> j}. The TDI generating this loop is, by Lemma 4.5.4, H + E(j), E(j)(s) = K(s)[K(s) Bj(s)] + (K(s)[H(s)] H(s)). To get the desired bounds on the TDI E(j), we use Lemma 4.5.2 and DuhamelsSince H Bj and K are split at (j, j + 1), we deduce that E(j) is split as well. formula. 4.7.2 Approximate splitting into factors In the previous subsection, we constructed anchored interactions E(j) that each split the loop at the edge (j, j + 1). Now we will try to split a loop at all edges (Rn, Rn + 1) at once, with n and R a large even integer. We will however only succeed to do this approximatively, and we will obtain the representation Z H = F W Z where F, W, Z are G-invariant TDIs depending on the parameter R such that i. W is small in the sense that |||W |||f f(R). ii. F is factorized over the intervals In and Z is factorized over the intervals Jn (both In, Jn have length R and they are defined below). iii. F, Z are close to generating loops: for each n, ||( F (1))In|| f(R), and analogously for Z. The first item is proven as a consequence of Lemma 4.7.4. The second item will be manifest by construction, and the third item is shown in Lemmas 4.7.5 and 4.7.6. We sketch the rough idea of the proof in Figure 4.5. H F H + m E(Rm) In1 In In+1 H F Z Jn Jn+1 Figure 4.5: We represent TDIs by a spatial function, so that edges at which the TDI is split correspond to zeros of this function. By implementing the loop-splitting procedure of Section 4.7.1 at multiple edges, we obtain the TDI F that is split over intervals In and that generates an (approximate) loop. The difference H F is then split over the intervals Jn. Since H and F generate (approximate) loops with basepoint , the almost local evolution F1 H also generates an (approximate) loop with basepoint . The TDI Z that generates the latter approximate loop would naturally be equal to H F in the limit of small H and F . In general, Z is not approximately equal to H F , but it does inherit a crucial property of H F , namely being (nearly) split over the intervals Jn. In the present and next sections, 4.7.2 and 4.7.3 all TDIs and all states will be G-invariant, and we will not repeat this. Indeed, the triviality of the index of our original loop was used heavily in Section 4.7.1 to argue that the pumped state can be connected to the basepoint, but in the remainder of the proof it plays no role. Splitting the loop into factorized quasiloops Let us introduce the intervals In = [Rn + 1, R(n + 1)], Jn = [R(n 12 ) 1, R(n + 12 )] (n Z). We note first that all four of these interactions depend on the parameter R and this is the parameter that controls the smallness, namely Lemma 4.7.3. |||F F|||f f(R) To avoid confusion, we remind that the two functions called f in the above expression need not be equal, as explained at the beginning of Section 4.7. Proof. Since H + E(Rn) is split at site Rn, the only interaction terms in F = H + n E(Rn) that contain Rn arise from E(Rn) with n n and hence they correspond to a set S with diam(S) R. More generally, every term in F F is of the form FS with diam(S) R. Therefore |||F F|||f f(R)|||F|||f. As we already remarked that |||F|||f C, the lemma is proven. Lemma 4.7.4. |||Z Z|||f f(R). 4P.r5o.o4f. We recall that Z is defined by Z = F1 H and therefore, by Lemma Z(s) = H (s) F (s) iH1(s)[ s H (u){[H (u) F (u), F (s, u){F (s)}]}du ] 0 (4.7.3) We write H F = D1 + D2, D2 = E(Rn), D1 = F F, n and we note the following properties |||D1|||f f(R), |||D2|||RZ,f C The bound on D1 follows from Lemma 4.7.3. The bound on D2 is by Lemma 4.5.2 item iii) and Lemma 4.7.2. Since Z is derived from Z by omitting such terms, we have |||Z Z|||f |||D1|||f f(R)|||D2|||f 2f(R) + which ends the proof. F and Z generate quasiloops We have established that F and Z are manifestly split; F is decoupled over intervals In and Z is decoupled over intervals Jn. So in particular we have that both F and Z are factorized over intervals of length R. Next, in Lemmas 4.7.5 and 4.7.6, we investigate how close those states are to , namely how close F, Z are to generating genuine loops. Lemma 4.7.5. Let = F (1). Then ||( )|In|| f(R) Proof. We partition, see Figure 4.6, In = I I+, I = In Jn, I+ = In Jn+1. Let us first estimate ||( )|I+ ||. Let Fn = H + E(Rn). Then Fn generates a loop with basepoint by Lemma 4.7.2 and we have, for A AI+ , (A) (A) = (Fn (1)[A] F (1)[A]) (4.7.4) We note now that the TDI F Fn = nn E(Rn) is anchored at distance at least R/2 from I, see Figure 4.6 and Lemma 4.5.2. Therefore, by Lemma 4.5.5, the integrand is bounded by f(R)||A||. We next estimate ||( )|I|| by the same argument but this time using Fn+1 = H + E(R(n+1)), so that, again F Fn+1 is anchored at distance R/2 from the relevant region I. We have thus obtained ||( )I || f(R) By a simple Lemma A.1.1 in Appendix A.1, these two bounds together imply that ||( )In|| 12f(R) which ends the proof. Lemma 4.7.6. Let = Z1(1). Then ||( )|Jn|| f(R). Proof. Recalling that Z = F1 H, we have = H1(1) F (1) Z(1) Z1(1) = F (1) Z(1) Z1(1), where the last equality follows because H generates a loop with basepoint . Now we estimate |(A) (A)| | F (1)[A] [A]| + ||A Z(1) Z1(1)[A]|| (4.7.5) for A AJn , and we deal with both terms separately. For the first term, we use that Jn is contained in the union In In+1. Employing Lemma 4.7.5 for the intervals In, In+1 and Lemma A.1.1, we can bound this term by ||A||f(R). For the second term in (4.7.5), we note that ZZ1 is generated by W = Z[ZZ], 4.5.2 to ||W||f f(R) and hence to the estimate see Lemma 4.5.3. The smallness of Z Z, see Lemma 4.7.4 leads via Lemma ||A W (1)[A]|| 1 ds||[W (s), A]|| f(R)|Jn|||A|| 0 Since |Jn| grows linearly in R, it can be absorbed in f(R). Therefore, (4.7.5) is bounded by f(R)||A||, as required. Let us check that we achieved the result described at the beginning of Section 4.7.2. We write H = F F1 H = F Z Z1 ( ) Z = F W Z and the desired properties of F, Z, W are manifest from the results above. 4.7.3 Final stage of the proof of Proposition 4.7.1 Closing the product quasi-loops Up to now, we have defined the TDIs F, Z that are split on intervals of length R. They do not generate loops, but they fail to do so by an error which decays fast in R. We now show that, by modifying F, Z by a small term that is split as well, the quasi-loops are made into genuine loops. Lemma 4.7.7. There are TDIs E = E(R), L = L(R) such that i. |||E|||f 0 and |||L|||f 0, as R . ii. E is split over the intervals In and L is split over the intervals Jn. iii. F E and L Z are loops with basepoint . Proof. Both F (1) and are factorized exactly over intervals In. We consider each interval separately and we note that we are exactly in the framework of Lemma 4.6.5. For each n, we obtain a time-dependent observable En() in AInthat generates parallel transport from (F(1))In to In, with norm bounded by ||( F (1) )In || f(R). We then assemble the different En() into a TDI: ES (s) = En(s) for S = In for some n and ES (s) = 0 otherwise. This TDI E satisfies F (1) E (1) = . To get a bound on E, note that for any h F , |||E|||h sup supsh||(ERn)(s)||. (4.7.6) n We choose h = f, and so we obtain |||E|||f f(R). This proves all claims concerning E. We now do the same for Z1, but replacing now In by Jn and calling the resulting (split and small) interaction L1. This achieves that = Z1(1) L1(1) and hence also = L(1) Z(1). Contracting product loops In the above sections, we have produced G-loops factorized over a collection of sets Yn. In our case Yn = In or Yn = Jn. We will now show that such a loop is contractible, i.e. homotopic to a constant loop. Lemma 4.7.8. Consider a G-loop that is factorized over intervals Yn, with Yn forming a partition of Z. If diam(Yn) is bounded uniformly in n, then is homotopic to a constant loop with the same basepoint. It is intuitively clear that this lemma relies on the fact that zero-dimensional systems dont allow for nontrivial loops because B(H) is simply connected. However, our notion of loops and their homotopy for states on spin chain algebras, does not simply reduce, in the case the chain is finite, to the standard notion of continuous loops and homotopy on topological spaces. The reason is that we require the loops to be generated by a TDI, which, even for loops on B(H), is a stronger notion than continuity. Actually, the requirement of being generated by a zero-dimensional TDI E(), as defined before Lemma 4.6.6, is in that case equivalent to absolute continuity of the loop. For this reason, we actually need an additional lemma on zero-dimensional loops. Lemma 4.7.9. Let s (s) be a loop of pure normal states on B(H), with H a finite-dimensional Hilbert space, and E() a zero-dimensional TDI with |||E||| = sups ||E(s)|| < such that (s) = (0) E(s). Then, there is a two-dimensional family of pure normal states (s) with , s [0, 1], and zero-dimensional TDIs E(), Fs() such that i. sup |||E||| 80|||E||| and sups |||Fs||| 208 ii. 1(s) = (0) = (1) = (0) = (1) for all s, . iii. (s) = (0) E(s) iv. (s) = (s) Fs() v. If the loop () is G-invariant, then the family (s) and the families E(s), Fs() can also be chosen G-invariant. As the proof of this lemma uses only standard expressions on parallel transport on Hilbert spaces, we postpone it to the appendix. Proof of Lemma 4.7.8. Let E be the TDI generating the factorized loop , with basepoint . Then ((s))Yn is a loop of pure, G-invariant states on AYn. Since AYn is isomorphic to B(HYn) through the map 1, we can apply Lemma 4.7.9 for every n separately. We first obtain then the time-dependent operators E,n() and Fs,n() in B(HYn ). We then assemble these time-dependent operators in two TDIs by setting E,S = {1(En,) 0 Fs,S = {1(Fn,) 0 so that we get, for any h F , S = Yn otherwise S = Yn otherwise |||E|||h sup n |h|E(|Yn,n||)|, |||Fs|||h sup h||(F|Yn,ns||)| n By the bounds of Lemma 4.7.9, and the assumption supn |Yn| < , we get that these norms are finite. It is straightforward to check that E() is a homotopy of loops connecting the original loop () to the constant loop with basepoint . CONTRACTIBILITY OF SHORT LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT 97 Proof of Proposition 4.7.1 We start from the identity H = F (Z Z1) Z We now use Lemma 4.7.7 by bringing in the almost local evolutions E,L defined therein and bracketing terms judiciously: H = (F E ) E1 Z Z1 L1 ( ) (L Z ). At this point, we see that the first and third bracketed evolutions generate loops with basepoint . Since H also generates a loop with basepoint , we conclude that also the second bracketed term generates a loop with basepoint . By Lemma 4.5.9, the above almost local evolution is homotopic to the concatenation of 3 loops7. (F E ) E1 Z Z1 L1 ( ( ) ) (L Z ) The first and third loop are product loops, hence contractible by Lemma 4.7.8. It follows that the loop H is homotopic to the loop , where H H = E1 Z Z1) L1. ( Just as all of E, Z, Z, L constructed above, the TDI H depends on the parameter R and we write H(R). Since Z Z is small (Lemma 4.7.4) and E, L are small in the same sense, we get from Lemma 4.5.4 and Lemma 4.5.2, that also H is small in this sense, e.g. ||H||f f(R). 4.8 Contractibility of short loopswith product basepoint In this section, we prove that short loops, i.e. where the TDI has small norm, with product basepoint, are G-homotopic to a constant loop. The more precise statement is below in Proposition 4.8.1. As before, we fix to be a G-state that is a product. 7Concatenation of loops is not an associative operation. However, Lemma 4.5.9 shows that (H1 H2)H3 is homotopic to H1 (H2 H3), since the composition is associative. Therefore we allow ourselves here to write simply . . . . . . . . .. Proposition 4.8.1. For any f F, there is an 1(f), such that, if |||H|||f 1(f) for a G-invariant TDI H that generates a loop H, then this loop is G-homotopic to the trivial loop with basepoint , and the homotopy can be chosen to have constant basepoint. 4.8.1 Construction of a loop of ground states First we rescale the given G-loop H to (s) = { H(2s) s 1/2, s > 1/2, (4.8.1) so that now (1/2) = . The resulting loop is G-homotopic to the original one by Lemma 4.5.9 item i). Next, we construct a specific G-invariant interaction F , tailored to the product state : F has only on-site terms Fi = 1 Pi with Pi the orthognonal projection on the range of the state |i. It follows that for any finite S, iS Fi has a simple eigenvalue 0, corresponding to the state |S, and it has no other spectrum below 1. We now define the G-invariant interaction F i 02s du H(2s){[H(u), F]} s 1/2, + Z(s) = (2s 1)F + (2 2s)Z(1/2) s > 1/2. Note that we have obtained a loop of interactions, since Z(1) = Z(0) = F. We will contract this loop of interactions to a point (namely F) by setting Z(s) = Z(0) + (1 )(Z(s) Z(0)), [0, 1]. This two-parameter family of interactions has the property that it remains close to F , as we remark now. Lemma 4.8.1. If |||H |||f 1, then, for f affiliated to f , i. ||Z(s) F ||f ii. There are G-invariant TDIs X(), Xs() such that s Z(s) Z(0) = duX(u), Z(s) Z0(s) = dXs() 0 0 iii. The TDIs from item ii) are uniformly bounded sup(|||X|||f + |||Xs|||f) s, CONTRACTIBILITY OF SHORT LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT Proof. Item i) follows directly from the definition of Z, using Lemma 4.5.2, and ||F||f = f(1). To satisfy items ii) and iii), we identify, X(s)= H(2s)[H(2s),F] s1/2 s>1/2 , 2F 2Z(1/2) Xs() = (Z(s) Z(0)) and we obtain the bounds similarly to item i). To continue, we recall the notion of a ground state in the infinite-volume setting of quantum lattice systems. Definition 4.8.2. A state on a spin chain algebra A is a ground state associated to an interaction K iff. (A[K, A]) 0, A Aal We will need two particular properties of a ground state. The first one is its invariance under the dynamics generated by the constant TDI K(s) = K: = K(s), s [0, 1] (4.8.2) It follows by using that [K, ] is a derivation. Indeed, [K, AA] = A[K, A] (A[K, A]) and hence ([K, AA]) = 0 for a ground state , which implies (4.8.2). The other property is the following variational statement, see Theorem 6.5.52 in [13]. Lemma 4.8.3. Let X be a finite subset of Z and let K be an interaction. Consider the functional eX,K : P(A) (recall that P(A) is the set of states) given by C eX,K() = (KS) S:SX Then, any ground state satisfies eX,K () = min :|Xc =|Xc eX,K () This property makes explicit the fact that ground states minimize the energy locally. The relevant to our problem is that we have a loop of ground states of explicitly given interactions, namely Lemma 4.8.4. For all s [0,1], (s) is a ground state of the interaction Z(s). Proof. Definition 4.8.2 makes it explicit that the property of being a ground state depends only on the derivation association to the interaction Z(s). For s [0,1/2], we have Z(s) H(2s)[F] and therefore the fact that (s)) is a ground state of Z(s) follows directly from being a ground state of F. For s > 1/2, we have Z(s) (2s 1)F + (2 2s)H(12)[F] and we use that H(12) = . Therefore is a ground state of both F and H(12)[F] and hence also of their convex combinations. 4.8.2 Construction of the homotopy via spectral flow Our main idea to prove Proposition 4.8.1 is to consider the 2-parameter family of states given by groundstates of the two-parameter family Z(s). To make such considerations less subtle, we first remark, in Proposition 4.8.2, that these groundstates are unique in the perturbative regime (small perturbations of product states). Results of that kind have been established in great generality in [66, 14, 39, 45]. However, the specific claim that we need does not seem to appear in the literature, mainly because we consider the infinite-volume setup. Therefore we provide a proof in Appendix A.3. Proposition 4.8.2. For any h F, there is a 2(h) > 0 such that, if ||W||h 2(h), then the interaction F + W has a unique ground state. If we choose 1(f ) in Proposition 4.8.1 small enough, then, by Lemma 4.8.1, all of the interactions Z(s) satisfy the condition of the above proposition and hence they have a unique ground state, that we call (s). This two-dimensional family (s, ) (s) is the homotopy that will realise Proposition 4.8.1. Indeed, for any , we have Z(0) = Z(1) = F , which has as the unique ground state, and hence (0) = (1) = . For = 0, the family (s) reduces to the loop (), as we had already remarked that this was a loop of ground states of Z(). For = 1, we have that Z1(s) = F , and hence 1() = Id. It remains to show that the family (s, ) (s) is generated by a TDI in and s directions. Such TDI will be obtained from the so-called spectral flow [28, 8, 40]. Proposition 4.8.3 below is the precise result on spectral flow that we will use. Such results appear in the literature for a much wider class of interactions instead of only F , see e.g. [14, 39, 45]. Even though none of these references covers explicitly the case we need, no extra idea is needed for the proof of Proposition 4.8.3, and we comment on it in Appendix A.3. To avoid a clash of notation, we use z [0, 1] (instead of s, ) as time-parameter in a TDI. CLASSIFICATION OF LOOPS WITH PRODUCT BASEPOINT Proposition 4.8.3. For any h F, there is 0< 3(h) < 1 such that, for any pair of TDIs W and Y satisfying z |||W|||h 3(h), |||Y |||h < , W(z) W(0) = dzY (z), (4.8.3) 0 the following holds: There exists a TDI satisfying ||| |||h |||Y |||h for h F depending only on h, such that, if the pure state is a ground state of F + W(0), then (z) = (0) (z), z [0, 1] (4.8.4) is a ground state of the interaction F + W (z). If Y is G-invariant, then also can be chosen G-invariant. Based on this result we can finish in a straighforward way the Proof of Proposition 4.8.1. By choosing in Lemma 4.8.1 small enough, we can apply the spectral flow technique, i.e. Proposition 4.8.3, to get generating TDIs for the paths s (s), and (s). They are uniformly bounded in ||| |||h by Proposition 4.8.3 and hence they provide the desired homotopy. By combining Proposition 4.8.1 with Proposition 4.7.1 we conclude Theorem 4.8.5. Let be a product G-state and let () = H() be a G-loop such that I(, H) = 0, i.e. its index is zero, then the loop is homotopic to the constant loop Id, via a homotopy with constant basepoint. This theorem will be the main tool in the next Section 4.9. 4.9 Classification of loops with product basepoint We are now ready to state a full result for the case of loops with a fixed product basepoint. Throughout this section, we again let be a pure, G-invariant product state and we consider it fixed. 4.9.1 Well-definedness of the index Up to now, the index I(, H) was defined as a function of the TDI H and the basepoint . We prove now that for product basepoint, it actually depends only on the loop itself and not on the choice of TDI that generates it. Lemma 4.9.1. Let H1,H2 be G-invariant TDIs that generate loops with basepoint. If H1(s)=H2(s), s[0,1], i.e. if the loops are equal, then the relative charge of the pumped states H1(s), H2(s) is zero and hence I(, H1) = I(, H2). Proof. By the same estimate as in Lemma 4.6.3 combined with Lemma 4.6.2, we deduce that H1 (s) and H2 (s) are mutually normal for all s [0, 1]. Therefore, the states (s) = H1(s) H12(s) are normal to and the path s (s) can be represented as a path of G-invariant, pure, normal states on B(H), with H the GNS Hilbert space associated to . Moreover, since s H(s)[A] is continuous for any A A and TDI H, we get that s (s) is continuous in weak -topology. Hence, item ii) of Proposition 4.3.1 implies that the states (s) have zero relative charge with respect to , and it follows then that also the mutually normal states H1(s) and H2(s) have zero relative charge. The claim of the lemma then follows by item i) of Proposition 4.3.1. In particular, this result means that we can now consistenly use the notation h() for a loop , instead of the more tedious object I(, H). 4.9.2 Additivity of the index Lemma 4.9.2. Let the TDIs H1 and H2 generate G-loops 1, 2 with common product basepoint . Then h(2 1) = h(2) + h(1) Proof. The pumped state of the loop 21 is H1(1)H2(1) (4.9.1) where, as before, Hj are the truncated TDI. We let H2(r) denoted the TDI truncated between sites r and r + 1 instead of the sites 0 and 1. By Lemma 4.5.6, we can replace H2 by H2(r) , such that the resulting pumped state (r) = H1(1) H2(r)(1) has the same charge as the state (4.9.1), for any r. Let CH be a constant such that |||H1|||f, |||H2|||f CH for some f F.
