Let 0 and 1 be G-invariant loops with common basepoint . If 0 and 1 are G-homotopic, then h(1) = h(0). Proof. We consider a homotopy (s) relating 0 and 1, as defined in Section 4.3.2, with the families of TDIs H and Fs, and we set C0 = sup(|||H|||f + |||F|||f ), s, with C0 finite by the condition (4.3.2). Moreover, for every , the TDI H generates a loop. For later reference, let us also define the loop () = (0) = (1). (4.9.8) where the last equality follows from the fact that () is a loop for every . Moreover, is a loop with basepoint because the loops 0 and 1 both have basepoint . We now take the set S = S(f, , C0) as defined in Section 4.6.3 and we take as furnished by Proposition 4.6.1. Note that depends on S. We set N = 1/(C0) and TN = {0, 1/N, . . . , 1}. For any t T2N \ {1}, we denote by t its successor, i.e. t = t + 21N . We consider functions x : T2N TN2 that satisfy i. x(0) = (0, 0) ii. x(1) = (1, 1) iii. x(t) x(t) equals either (1/N, 0) or (0, 1/N ). and we call such functions admissible walks, By drawing a straight line between x(t) and x(t), we obtain a piecewise linear path in the unit square, starting at the bottom-left corner (0, 0) and ending in the top-right corner (1, 1), and always moving either upwards or to the right, see Figure 4.7 and 4.9 for examples. To every admissible walk x, we associate a TDI Dx() as follows: for s (t, t], we set Dx(s) = {2Hx1(t)((x2(t) + 2(s t)) if x(t) x(t) = (0, 1 N ) 2Fx2(t)((x1(t) + 2(s t)) if x(t) x(t) = ( N1 , 0) (4.9.9) This construction is illustrated in Figure 4.7. Every one of such TDIs Dx generates a loop with basepoint . This follows from the definition of homotopy given in Section 4.3.2, in particular from the fact that H and Fs generate motion on the two-dimensional sheet of states (s, ) (s). 1 s Fs3 H1 s3 s2 Fs2 H3 x() s1 Fs1 H2 H1 F0 1 2 3 1 Figure 4.7: The TDI associated to the walk x is represented in the square [0,1]2. The upward steps are generated by H, the right-moving steps are generated by F. 1 s 1 N 1 1 N Figure 4.8: Two walks that are adjacent. They delineate a small square with sides of length 1/N . We say that two distinct admissible walks x, y are adjacent if x(t) = y(t) for all, but one value of t T2N , that we call t. It follows that x, y are obtained from each other by flipping the steps between preceding and following the time t, i.e. and upwards step becomes right-moving, and vice versa, see Figure 4.8. We then note that for x, y adjacent admissible walks, we have |||Dx Dy|||(f1) C0/(2N) By Proposition 4.6.1, and the choice of N made above, we have h(Dx) = h(Dy). Therefore, two admissible walks give rise to loops with the same index if those walks can be deformed into each other by switching a walk into an adjacent one. Consider then the two admissible walks x(t) = {(0, 2t) (2(t 12 ), 1) y(t) = {(2t, 0) (1, 2(t 12 )) t 1 2 t > 12 t 1 2 t > 12 These walks can be transformed into each other, as we illustrate in Figure 4.9. The walk xcorrespond to the loop 1 and the walk y corresponds to 0. These two loops have hence the same index and by using the additivity Lemma 4.9.2, we conclude that h() + h(0) = h(1) + h() x() y() Figure 4.9: Transformation of the walk x() into y() via a path of adjacent walks. which implies h(0) = h(1). 4.9.4 Homeomorphism property of h We have already established that h maps the concatenation of loops into the sum of charges. We would like to state that h is a homeomorphism, but as it stands, the concatenation of loops admits neither an identity nor an inverse. This can be remedied by using (G)-homotopy to define equivalence classes of loops. The following lemma shows that h acts as a homeomorphism from homotopy classes to H1. Let Id be the constant loop with basepoint , i.e. (s) = , and recall the definition of the inverse (s) = (1 s) associated to a loop . Lemma 4.9.3. Let be a G-invariant loop with basepoint . Then i. h(Id) = 0 ii. is G-homotopic to Id. iii. h() = h() Proof. Item i) follows because a possible TDI generating constant loops is H = 0, and for that TDI, the pumped state is equal to the basepoint. To show item ii), we consider the following homotopy: (s) = {(((1+(1)2s))(2s 1)) ss > 11//22 (4.9.10) We note that ((1 )2s) = ( + (1 )(2s 1)), for s = 1/2 by the definition of , resolving the apparent incongruence between s 1/2 and s > 1/2 in the definition of (s). The homotopy property of (s, ) () now follows because , are loops and using Lemma 4.5.9 item i). We then remark that 0() = , 1() = Id Id = Id which settles item ii). Finally, by additivity and item i): h() + h() = h( ) = h(Id) = 0 which implies item iii). 4.9.5 Completeness of classification We now prove that our classification is complete. Lemma 4.9.4. If a pair of G-invariant loops 1() and 2() have equal index, then they are G-homotopic. Proof. Indeed, the loop 2 1 has index zero, by Lemma 4.9.3 and Lemma 4.9.2. By Theorem 4.8.5, this loop is G-homotopic to the constant loop Id. Let (s) be this homotopy, satisfying also (0) = (1) = . We now construct two derived homotopies and by (s) = {(s()2s1)(1/2) (s) = {(1(2ss1))(1/2) s 1/2 s > 1/2 s 1/2 s > 1/2 (4.9.11) (4.9.12) The apparent incongruence at s = 1/2 is resolved by noting that (s) = (2s1)(1/2) for s = 1/2. The fact that s (s) and (s) are generated by uniformly bounded TDIs, follows from the fact that (s, ) (s) is a homotopy and from Lemma 4.5.7. Then, by construction, 0(1/2) = and (0) = so that () are loops with basepoint . This confirms that (s, ) (s) is indeed a homotopy. In an analogous way, one checks that (s, ) (s) is a homotopy. In Figure 4.10, we illustrate how and are derived from . We define also the path (z) = z(1/2) and note that this path is in fact a loop. Indeed, (1) = because the original homotopy reduces for = 1 to Id, and (0) = 0(1/2) = as already used above. We are now ready to analyze the homotopies and . For = 0, it reduces to Id 1. s 2 () Id 1 () Figure 4.10: We square represents the homotopy (s, ) (s). In this square we show the loops () and () building the homotopies and . For = 1, it reduces to Id . (4.9.13) It is also represented in Figure 4.10. To verify that is a homotopy, we proceed analogously as for . The homotopy reduces for = 0 to the loop Id 2 and for = 1 to the loop (4.9.13). Hence, we conclude that Id 1 and Id 2 are homotopic to the same loop (4.9.13) and hence to each other. It follows that 1 is homotopic to 2. 4.10 Proof of main theorems In Section 4.9, we proved all results of this paper in the special case of loops with product basepoint. In the present section, we prove our results without this restriction by relying on the results in Section 4.9. Indeed, by the assumption of invertibility, we can reduce all our results to statements about loops with product basepoint. We use the terminology introduced at the beginning of Section 4.3.4. PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS 4.10.1 Proof of Proposition 4.4.1 Let H() be loop. We let be an inverse to the basepoint , such that = 1 (4.10.1) where is a product state and = E(1) for some TDI E. As in the text preceding Proposition 4.4.1, we let = H(1) with H the truncated TDI. Let also = 1 (4.10.2) By the uniqueness of the GNS-representation, normality of w.r.t. is equivalent to normality of w.r.t. . By (4.10.1) and (4.10.2), it is therefore also equivalent to normality of w.r.t. . By equation (4.5.5), we have (here we write H for H id) = H(1) 1 = (H)(1) Since (H)() is a loop with product basepoint, the state (H)(1) is normal with respect to by Lemma 4.6.3. Moreover, by Lemma 4.5.6, and the fact that (H) (H) is a TDI anchored in a finite set, we get that (H)(1) is normal with respect to (H)(1). Since normality of pure states is a transitive relation, the claim is proven. 4.10.2 Loops whose basepoint is G-equivalent to a product As a first step in dealing with loops with non-product basepoint, we formulate a lemma for loops whose basepoint is G-equivalent to a product state. Lemma 4.10.1. Let be a G-loop generated by the TDI H, such that, for some G-invariant TDI K and a product state , = (0) K1(1). Then the loop is homotopic to the loop = ((K H ) K ) (4.10.3) which has product basepoint . Moreoever, their indices are equal, i.e. I((0),H) = h() (4.10.4) =1 0<<1 =0 (0) (0) (0) Figure 4.11: The homotopy moves the basepoint (0) up to the product state . Proof. We note that the loop is such that the evolution K is traversed between times s = 0 and s = 1/4, H is traversed between s = 1/4 and s = 1/2, and K is traversed between s = 1/2 and s = 1. We define the homotopy, illustated in Figure 4.11, s 1/4 (s) = (s) (/4 + (1 )s) 1/4 < s < 1/2 (1/2 + (s 1/2)(1 )) 1/2 s We note first that there is no incongruence at s = 1/4 and s = 1/2 since, for any , (1/4) = (1/4) = (0) = (1) = (1/2) = (1/2) From Lemma 4.5.7, we see that the family (s, ) (s) is generated by uniformly bounded TDIs in s and direction. To conclude that this family is homotopy, we check that it is a loop for all , using the definition of time-reversed loops; (0) = (/4) = () = (1 ) = (1 /2) = (1). This homotopy connects the loop with the loop (Id(0) ) Id(0) and the latter is clearly homotopic to , which settles the first claim of the lemma. Since we have not yet proven in general that homotopy preserves the index, we need another argument to get (4.10.4). The pumped state of the loop () is K(1)H(1)(K)(1) = K(1)H(1)K1(1) = K(1)[H](1) where the first expression follows because (K) = (K) with K the TDI generating K, i.e. K(s) = K(1 s). Then, we observe that K(1)[H] K(1)[H] is a G-invariant TDI anchored in {0, 1}. That follows by Duhamels principle from the fact that [K K, H] is anchored in {0, 1} and from Lemma 4.5.2. PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS This implies then by Lemma 4.5.6 item ii) that the pumped state has zero relative charge w.r.t. the state [H](1) = H(1) 1 where we abbreviated = K(1). Hence to prove the claim of the lemma, we have to show that the relative charge of H(1) 1 w.r.t. equals the relative charge of H(1) w.r.t. since the latter are the pumped state and basepoint, respectively, of the loop . This equality of relative charges follows then from item v) of Proposition 4.3.1, taking = . 4.10.3 Tensor products Given two G-loops 1, 2 on spin chain algebras A1, A2, generated by TDIs H1, H2, we can consider the product loop 1 2 on the spin chain algebra A1 A2, generated by the TDI H1 Id + Id H2. The truncation of this TDI to the left equals the sum of truncated TDIs H1 Id + Id H2 and it then follows that the pumped state is given by a tensor product of pumped states 1(0) H1(1) 2(0) H2(1) From Proposition 4.3.1 item iii), it then follows that the index is additive, i.e. I(1(0) 2(0), H1 Id +H2 Id) = I(1(0), H1) + I(2(0), H2) We will establish in the next sections that the index depends only on the loop and not on the generating TDI, but we can already see that, if a loop is generated by the TDI H = 0, then its index is zero. This observation allows us to extend any G-loop generated by H to a G-loop Id, with a G-state, generated by H Id, such that the index does not change, i.e. I((0) , H1 Id) = I((0), H) (4.10.5) Such operations will be used repeatedly in what follows. 4.10.4 The associated loop The main tool that we will use in the remaining proofs is that every G-loop can be related to a loop with product basepoint, such that they have the same index. We consider hence a general G-loop and we let (0) be a G-inverse to (0). By the discussion in Section 4.10.3, the loop Id(0) has the same index as . However, the former loop has a basepoint that is G-equivalent to a product state and hence we can invoke Lemma 4.10.1 to construct a loop A, which we call the associated loop, that has a product basepoint, and it is such that Lemma 4.10.2. Let be a G-loop generated by the TDI H. There is a G-loop A with product basepoint such that h(A) = I((0),H). We will use the associated loops frequently in the analysis below. 4.10.5 Proof of Theorem 4.3.8 and 4.4.1 Well-definedness of the index Given a loop generated by a TDI H, we have argued that we can define an associated loop A with the same index, in the sense of Lemma 4.10.2. If we have two TDIs H1, H2 that both generate the loop , we see, by the definition of associated loops, that the associated loops can be chosen equal. Hence, by the results in Section 4.9.1, their index is equal and hence also I((0), H1) = I((0), H2). Therefore, also for loops with a non-product basepoint, the index I(, ) depends only on the loop itself. We can henceforth use the notation h(). In particular, this means that Theorem 4.4.1 is proven once we establish all the properties of the index h() claimed in Theorem 4.3.8, which we do now. Proof of Theorem 4.3.8 We now check the items of Theorem 4.3.8 one by one. Item i) If a loop is constant, we can choose the generating TDI H = 0. In that case the pumped state equals the basepoint and the index is manifestly equal to zero. Item ii) The examples described in Section 4.4.2 realize every h H1(G). PROOF OF MAIN THEOREMS Item iii) Let the G-loops 1, 2 be stably G-homotopic. From Section 4.10.3, we know that by adjoining constant loops with product basepoint, we can make these loops G-homotopic without changing their respective indices. Hence without loss of generality we assume henceforth that 1, 2 are G-homotopic. Consider an associated loop 1A with product basepoint , obtained by adjoining an inverse 1(0). Since 1(0) and 2(0) are G-equivalent, so are 1(0) 1(0) and 2(0) 1(0) and hence also 2 has an associated loop 2A with basepoint . Since for j = 1, 2 the loop j is stably G-homotopic to the loop jA, and the loops 1, 2 are G-homotopic to each other, also 1A, 2A are G-homotopic. Since they share a product basepoint, these loops have equal index, by the results in Section 4.9. By Lemma 4.10.2 it then follows that also 1, 2 have equal index. Item iv) For a pair 1, 2 of G-loops with common basepoint, we find a pair of associated loops A1, 2A with common basepoint . We note first that (2 1)A is homotopic to 2A 1A which follows from Lemma 4.9.3 item ii. Since these are loops with product basepoint, the homotopy implies that they have the same index. The claim then follows from Lemma 4.10.2 and the additivity of the index for loops with product basepoint. Item v) This was already proven in Section 4.10.3. Item vi) If the G-loops 1, 2 have stably G-equivalent basepoints, then by adjoining a product state, the basepoints are G-equivalent. Without loss of generality, we assume hence that the basepoints of 1, 2 are G-equivalent. Let 1(0) be a G-inverse to 1(0), then we consider the loops j Id1(0) Id1(0), j = 1, 2 (4.10.6) and we argue that they are G-homotopic, which will yield the required stable G-homotopy of the original loops, since the adjoined product of constant loops is homotopic to a constant loop with product basepoint. To show that (4.10.6) are G-homotopic, we actually prove that j Id1(0) are G-homotopic. These respective loops are homotopic to the assocated loops jA, which can be chosen to have the same product basepoint, by the same reasoning as in item iv). From h(1) = h(2), we deduce that h(1A) = h(A2) and hence A1, A2 are G-homotopic by Lemma 4.9.4. Chapter 5 SPT indices emerging from translation invariance in two-dimensional quantum spin systems 5.1 Introduction In 2010, Chen, Gu and Wen [18] introduced the notion of symmetry-protected topological phases of matter (SPT). They first considered one dimensional matrix product states and later on, Chen, Liu and Wen [19], extended this to two dimensional projective entangled pair models. Afterwards, in [16] this was extended to other dimensions. This last reference used a setup involving so-called lattice nonlinear sigma models and provided an Hd+1(G, U (1)) valued index for any d-dimensional lattice nonlinear sigma model. Another possible setup in which one can define SPT phases is in quantum spin systems (defined in section 5.2.1). In order to define SPT phases in this setting, one needs to fix a finite group G with an on-site group action g Ug (with g G), defining a global group action g (also defined in section 5.2.1). A state , is then called G-invariant, if g = . Afterwards, one needs to impose a restriction on the 115 116 SPT INDICES EMERGING FROM TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN TWO-DIMENSIONAL QUANTUM SPIN SYSTEMSspace of states. We1 ask that our states are short range entangled (SRE), see definition 5.2.2. A state is short range entangled if there is a disentangler . This is a locally generated automorphism, produced by a one parameter family of interactions BF ([0, 1]) ( = 0;1 as defined in section 5.2.3) satisfying that is a product state. Combining these two definitions, we say that is an SPT state if it is short range entangled and G-invariant. One then defines an equivalence relation on these SPT states by saying that 1 is equivalent to 2 with respect to the on site group action U if there exists a G-invariant one parameter family of interactions BF ([0, 1]) such that 1 0;1 = 2 (again, see section 5.2.3 for the definitions). One can then extend this equivalence to the stronger notion of being stably equivalent. This goes as follows: one defines an operation called stacking that takes two SPT states 1 and 2 and outputs a third one 1 stack 2 (and similarly for the group action). This stack is defined in section 5.2.1. In short, it is the tensor product at the level of the on site Hilbert space. One then defines another equivalence (2, U2) are stably equivalent if and only if there exist trivial2 SPTs with their relation andsays that two SPT states with on site group actions (1, U1) and group actions, (1, 1) and (2, 2) and a (G independent) unitary V mapping between the respective on site Hilbert spaces3, such that i. V U1,g 1,gV = U2,g 2,g for all g G. ii. 1 stack 1 iV (where iV is again defined in section 5.2.1) is equivalent to 2 stack 2 with respect to the above on site group action. In one spatial dimension so called matrix product states ([19],[50],[54]) can be used to construct non-trivial SPT states. Later on and more generally it was shown in [47] that any G-invariant state satisfying the split property (this includes any SRE state) carries an H2(G, T)-valued4 index and that this index is constant on the (stable) equivalence classes. Later on in [33] it was then shown that this classification problem is complete (the index, seen as a map from the set of stable equivalence classes to H2(G,T) is injective.). In two spatial dimensions, more recently in [48], it was proven there is an H3(G,T)-valued1There are other definitions possible like for instance the concept of invertible G-invariant states used in [33] or the unique gapped ground state of a G invariant interaction presented in the introduction of [48]. 2A trivial state is a G-invariant product state that transforms trivially under the on site group action (see remark 5.5.11). 3The reader can think of this V as being a unitary transformation of the on site group action. 4By Hn(G, T) we mean the n-th (Borel) group cohomology of G with coefficients in the torus T (seen as a (group) module under addition with trivial group action). Group cohomology is defined in section 5.2.5. INTRODUCTION index that is constant on the (stable) equivalence classes5. Weve used stacking to define the stable equivalence relation. Stacking however plays a more general role. It widely believed that it allows us to define an (abelian) group structure on the set of stable equivalence classes6. Although it is nowhere stated explicitly, the author thinks that the literature (like for example [33]) suggests the following conjecture: Conjecture 5.1.1. Let S be the set of stable SPT classes for some fixed group and a fixed lattice. Let be the map : S2 S : (1, U1, 2, U2) 1 stack 2, U1 U2. (5.1.1) Then is well defined (independent of the choice of representative) and S together with the operation forms an abelian group. Before proceeding, we make three remarks on this conjecture: i. The claim that is well defined and abelian is trivial. Namely, by letting iV be the automorphism that exchanges the two algebras that are being stacked, one can exchange the order of the stacking freely. By using 1 0;11 stack 2 0;21 = (1 stack 2) 0;111+12 1 stack 2, (5.1.2) one can show that this is a well-defined map. ii. A representative of the inverse is sometimes called a G-inverse. iii. From a category point of view, if one assumes that this conjecture is true (for some subclass of groups that is a category), it is not hard to see that it gives rise to a contravariant functor from this category of groups to the category of abelian groups (say S[G]). More specifically, f : S[G2] S[G1] : , U , U f and this f is indeed invariantto each group morphism f : G1 G2, one can find a group morphismon the choice of representative (if two states can be connected while preserving the symmetry action , they can certainly be connected while preserving the symmetry f). In what follows, we will call S with the above group structure the stable SPT classification. In this paper we consider the 2D case with the (stable) equivalence 5In [48], there is no mention of the stacking operation but using remark 5.4.28 and remark 5.4.30, one can clearly extend it to the stable equivalence class. 6The stacking with a trivial state will then be related to the identity of this group SPIN SYSTEMS relation as presented here but with one notable difference. We will only consider states, interactions and on site symmetries that have a translation symmetry in one direction. There is a conjecture about the SPT classification of such states, see section 3.1.5.1 of [65] for a more general and detailed exposition (which was partially based on [16]). Conjecture 5.1.2. The set of translation invariant SPTs under stable equivalence7 also satisfies conjecture 5.1.1. Let g be the inclusion map from the space of 2d translation invariant SPT states to the more general set of 2d SPT states. Let f be the map that takes a 1d SPT state and outputs a translation invariant 2d SPT state by taking the tensor product in the direction of the translation symmetry. The sequence 0 {1d SPT states} f {2d translation invariant SPT states} g {2d SPT states} 0 (5.1.3) induces a sequence (of group morphisms) on the stable equivalence classes. By this we mean that the class of f () only depends on the class of and similarly for g. Moreover this induced sequence is exact and split. Clearly this implies that {2d translation invariant SPT classification} {1d SPT classification} {2d SPT classification}. (5.1.4) Since a 1d SPT state carries an H2(G, T) valued index and a 2d SPT state carries an H3(G,T) valued index, this means that 2d SPT states with a translation symmetry should carry an H2(G,T)H3(G,T) valued index. This is consistent with the result of section XII of [16]. The first result of this paper is the construction of an H2(G,T) valued index (which we will denote by Index) on the space of translation invariant SPT states that is consistent with conjectures 5.1.1 and 5.1.2. By being consistent with the conjecture it is meant (among other things) that, if Index1 is the one dimensional SPT index from [47], then Index(f()) = Index1() for any 1d SPT . This construction highly relies on the objects that are present in the construction of the 2d SPT index in [48]. We also look at the case where there is a second translation symmetry (so the system is translation invariant in both x and y directions). For such systems there is the following conjecture conjecture (see again [65] and [16]): 7In the stable equivalence relation for translation invariant states we ask that the on site symmetry is translation invariant and that any path connecting two states and each trivial state is not only G-invariant but also translation invariant. INTRODUCTION Conjecture 5.1.3. The space of SPTs, translation invariant in two directions under stable equivalence also satisfies conjecture 5.1.1. Let g be the inclusion map from the space of 2d SPT states that are translation invariant in both x and y directions to the more general set of 2d SPT states with translation invariance in the x direction only. Let f be the map that takes a 1d translation invariant SPT state and outputs a 2d SPT state that is translation invariant in both x and y directions by taking the tensor product in the y direction. The sequence 0 {1d translation invariant} {2d SPT states with two} {2d SPT states translation} SPT states f translation symmetries g invariant in x direction 0 (5.1.5) induces a sequence (of group morphisms) on the stable equivalence classes. By this we mean that the class of f () only depends on the class of and similarly for g. Moreover, this induced sequence is exact and split. Translation invariant SPT states in one spatial dimension are known to carry an H2(G, T) H1(G, T) valued index (see appendix B.8). From this and the last two conjectures, we expect there is an H3(G, T) H2(G, T) H2(G, T) H1(G, T) (5.1.6) valued index. The first part of the index is just Index2d. The following two parts can be related to the case of a single translation symmetry as follows. Let be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90 and let Index() be the index as constructed before (this is the second part of 5.1.6). The third part of the index is now given by Index( ) (the state rotated by 90). The last part of the index requires a different construction altogether. It can be thought of as being the charge in the Brillouin zone. A final remark: Remark 5.1.4. As noticed in [16]. The groups in which these indices take values can be concisely written out. Using that H0(Z,T) = T H1(Z,T) = T H2(Z,T) = 0 H3(Z,T) = 0 (5.1.7) and inserting this into the Knneth formula for G gives Z H2(Z G, T) = Hi(Z, T) H2i(G, T) = H2(G, T) H1(G, T) (5.1.8) 2 i=0 H3(Z G, T) = Hi(Z, T) H3i(G, T) = H3(G, T) H2(G, T). (5.1.9) 3 i=0 This result can in turn be used to work out the Knneth formula for Z2 G H 3 (Z2 G, T) = H i (Z, T) H 3i (Z G, T) = H 3 (G, T) H 2 (G, T) H 2 (G, T) H 1 (G, T). 3 i=0 (5.1.10) The layout of this paper is as follows: First in section 5.2 we explain the setup, define the concept of locally generated automorphisms and give the algebraic definition of group cohomology. In section 5.3.2 we state the two results for SRE states. In section 5.3.1, we state the first result using the weaker assumption 5.3.2 and the second result using the weaker assumption 5.3.5. It is using these weaker assumptions that we then prove the statements. Section 5.4 provides a proof of the first statement whereas section 5.5 provides a proof of the second statement. The results in this paper rely heavily on the methods that where developed in [48]. Acknowledgements T.J. was supported in part by the FWO under grant G098919N. We are grateful to the referees of Communications in Mathematical Physics for their constructive input during the review process. For example, we are very grateful for the proposed changes of lemma B.1.3, the mistake they found in subsection 5.4.4 (the previous assumption was too weak) and the mistakes they found in sections 5.4.5 and 5.5.4. SETUP AND DEFINITIONS 5.2 Setup and definitions In this paper we work in the two dimensional lattice some specific subsets of Z2, so let Z2. We will first need L := {(x,y) Z2|x < 0}, R := {(x,y) Z2|x 0} (5.2.1) U := {(x,y) Z2|y 0}, D := {(x,y) Z2|y < 0} (5.2.2) be the left, right, upper and lower half planes respectively and let C := { (x,y) Z2tan() xy} (5.2.3) be the horizontal cone (the green area in figure 5.1). We will use to denote the bijection that moves every element of Z2 one site upward. Similarly we let denote the bijection that translates every element of Z2 by one site to the right. In what follows we will sometimes need to widen our cone or other subsets of Z2 vertically by one site. For this purpose we define W such that for any Z2, W () := () 1(). (5.2.4) For example, the red area in figure 5.1 is W(C)c. In the later part we will also need to rotate our lattice by 90 (clockwise) so call the bijection on Z2 that does precisely this.8 Finally we will need to define the horizontal lines and the finite horizontal line Lj := {(i, j)|i Z} Lnj := {(i, j)|i Z [n, n]}. (5.2.5) 5.2.1 Quasi local C-algebra The setup in this paper will be very similar to the setup in [48] and is just the standard setup for defining quantum spin systems. For the rest of this paper, take d N+ arbitrary. This number will be called the on site dimension9. For each z Z2, let A{z} be an isomorphic copy of B(Cd) (the bounded oFApoloercraa=ntoyrsonG CG2dAZ)2., IwannedwsehdtaetfiAnfoell=tohwesq,zuleatsiGAloZ{cz2}ab.leCWtheaedlgseeefitbnroeaf tafihsnetithleoecsanulobrasmlegtescbloorfasuZar2es. of the local aZlgebra (A = Aloc). Similarly, for any (possibly infinite) subset 8We will not discuss rotation invariant states in this paper. The is only defined to make certain constructions work. 9In principle in the case were there is only one translation we can let d be x-dependent but for simplicity let us take d constant over the lattice. Z2 we set Aloc, = G A and A = Aloc, . Throughout this paper we will sometimes require a stronger form of locality than merely being in the norm completion of the local algebra. Specifically when = Lj is a horizontal line. We will say that an operator A ALj is summable if and only if there exists a sequence An ALnj on the finite horizontal lines such that A An < . (5.2.6) i=0 We will need to define some automorphisms on this algebra using the bijections defined previously. To this end, define the isomorphisms : A A () : A A() : A A() (5.2.7) as the translation upwards, the translation to the right and the right-handed rotation respectively. By construction, these isomorphisms are automorphisms if is taken to be Z2 (because d is a constant throughout the lattice). Clearly if = (by which we mean again the x-axis (Z,0)) only one of these translation automorphisms descends to an automorphism on AZ. This automorphism is Z then also simply denoted as . We will need to define one additional set of automorphisms. For any set of unitaries Vi U(Cd) (labelled by i Z2), we define the (unique) automorphism iV Aut(A) (for all Z2) such that iV (A) = Ad(iIVi)(A) (5.2.8) for all I finite and A AI . More specifically, let G be a finite group and let Ui hom(G,U(Ai)) (for i Z2) be the on site group action. Let hom(G,Aut(A)) (for any Z2) be such that g(A) = iU(g) = Ad(iIUi(g))(A) (5.2.9) for any g G, I finite and A AI. Clearly, any unitary transformation of our representation U() V U()V induces a transformation of the group action g iV1 g iV . Throughout our paper when we are discussing translation invariance in the vertical direction we will ask that the group action is translation invariant in the vertical direction ( g = g() ). If we also have translation invariance in the horizontal direction, we will also ask that the group action be translation invariant in that direction as well ( g = g() ). As it turns out, in showing that the H1-valued index is consistent with all the conjectures of the introduction, we will even require that the on site group action Ui(g) is the same at each site. In what follows we will always assume this. This means that when we denote an on site symmetry action we merely have to give one representation U hom(G,U(Cd)) and when we denote a unitary transformation of the on site Hilbert space we only have to give a single unitary V U(Cd), we will use this notation frequently. Clearly by construction there is a tensor product operation on this C algebra in the sense that for any 1, 2 Z2 satisfying that 1 2 = we can define a bilinear, surjective map : A1 A2 A12. (5.2.10) There is however a second tensor product operation on this C algebra that we will use. We will call it the stacking operation. It is such that for any 2 we define the bilinear, surjective map Z stack : A A A2 (5.2.11) where A2 is the quasi local C algebra on Z2 constructed from an on site algebra B(Cd) B(Cd) B(Cdd)10. We will also need to define the stacking of the group action by which we mean (g stack g) = Ad(U (g) U (g)z) (5.2.12) z for any GZ2 (in fact stacking can be defined for any automorphism, not just the group action). 5.2.2 States on A We say that a linear functional : A is a state if it positive and normalized. This means that for any A A, (AA) 0 and that (1) = 1. We denote the C set of states on A by S(A). In this paper we will work exclusively with states that are pure. In this setting, S(A) being pure means that it is extremal in the sense that for any p ]0,1[, the only two other states 1,2 S(A) that satisfy = p1 + (1 p)2 (5.2.13) 10Clearly this can also be used to stack two C-algebras with different on site Hilbert spaces, this was used in the introduction. In the rest of the paper we will for simplicity of notation (but without loss of generality) only stack two identical C-algebras on top of each other. must satisfy 1 = 2 = . The set of pure states on A will be called P(A). In this paper we will often refer to the GNS triple. For its definition, construction and properties we refer to [11]. We will sometimes write the tensor product of states to be such that ( )(a b) = (a)(b) and similarly for the stacking tensor product. We will call a pure state on A a product state if for any , the restriction |A is still pure. We will call a state , G-invariant if g = (where g = iU(g) with U an on site group action). Moreover, let U we say that a G-invariant product state is trivial with respect to U (we will sometimes denote this as (,U) is trivial) if (Ui(g)) = 1 for all i Z2. There is a natural way to construct a pure G-invariant state on the quasi local C-algebra over Z2, AZ2 using a pure G-invariant state on the quasi local C-algebra over Z, AL011. Definition 5.2.1. The proof that this is a well defined state is done in definition 5.4.17. 5.2.3 Interactions and locally generated automorphisms An interaction is a map : GZ2 Aloc : I (I) (5.2.15) where (I) AI is hermitian ((I) = (I)). We will sometimes require a norm on the space of interactions that indicates how local an interaction acts. Take F : R+ any monotonically decreasing positive function then we define N an F -norm on the space of interactions by: F := x,syupZ2 F (|x y|) ZG2,Zx,y (Z). 1 (5.2.16) Z 11When applied to a trivial state on AL0 this will also give a trivial state on AZ 2 . Following [48] we will fix a specific family of monotonically decreasing positive functions by saying that for any 0 < < 1 we define F : R+ R+ : r (1 + r)4 exp(r) . (5.2.17) We will sometimes use the restriction of an interaction. For some Z2 we define by : GZ2 Aloc : I {(I) oitfhIerwise. 0 (5.2.18) The set of interactions with this norm (for a fixed F ) is a Banach space. One of the properties of F -local interactions is that they can be used to generate automorphisms. Let : GZ2 [0, 1] Aloc : (I , t) (I , t) (5.2.19) be a norm continuous12 one parameter family of interactions such that the F - norm is uniformly bounded (supt[0,1] (, t)F < ). We will denote the set of one parameter families of interactions that satisfy this property by BF ([0, 1]). For any BF([0, 1]), we define the locally generated automorphism (LGA) s;t such that for any A A, s;t(A) is given as the solution to the differential equation dts;t(A) = i s;t([(I,t),A]) d (5.2.20) IG 2 Z with initial condition s;s(A) = A (the existence of this automorphism is proven in [44]). This satisfies the condition that if supt IB 2 (I, t) < then Z s;t = Ad(us;t) us;t := T expi s ds (s, t). (5.2.21) t IB 2 Z Sometimes we will say that an interaction is G-invariant. Let P (A). We say that is an SRE state if and only if there exists a ]0, 1[ such that there exists an interaction BF ([0, 1]) such that 0;1 is a product state. We then call 0;1 a disentangler for . On the set of G-invariant SRE states we will now define three stable equivalence classes depending on the additional imposed symmetry: Definition 5.2.3. Take (1, U1) and (2, U2) elements of S0 = {(, U ) P(A) hom(G, U (Cd))| is SRE, iU(g) = g G} (5.2.22) for two algebras A1 and A213. We say that 1, U1 = 2, U2 if and only if there exists a ]0, 1[ such that there exists a G-invariant interaction BF([0, 1]), trivial elements of S0 (see subsection 5.2.2), (1, 1) and (2, 2) for algebras 1 and 2 respectively and an on site unitary such that 1 stack 1 iV = 2 stack 2 0;1 V U1(g) 1(g)V = U2(g) 2(g). (5.2.23) We also define similar equivalence classes 1, 2 and 3 on S1 = { (, U ) P(A) hom(G, U (Cd)) is SRE, iU(g) = g G,} = (5.2.24) S2 = (, U ) P(A) hom(G, U (Cd)) is SRE, iU(g) = g G, } { = (5.2.25) S3 = { (, U ) P(A) hom(G, U (Cd)) is SRE, iU,(g)= g G, } = = (5.2.26) respectively. Here we now also demand that the interactions and the trivial states are invariant under the additional translation symmetries. 13With two different algebras we simply mean two different on site dimensions because we already fixed each on site dimension to be identical. 5.2.5 (Borel) Group cohomology groups In this paper we define the Group cohomology groups using the algebraic approach. A standard reference for Group cohomology is [9]. Let G be an arbitrary finite group. For any n N, let Cn(G,M) (in principle this can be for any (left) G-module M but in this paper we will always take M = with the addition and the trivial group action14) be the group of all functions from T Gn to M . We will use additive notation on this space and denote the group operator by + and the inverse of an element of the group by . Now define the coboundary homomorphisms dn+1 : Cn(G,M) Cn+1(G,M) (5.2.27) such that (dn+1)(g1, , gn+1 ) = g1(g2, , gn+1) + (1)i(g1, , gi1, gigi+1, , gn+1 n ) + (1)n+1(g1, , gn). i=1 (5.2.28) Since dn+1 dn = 0 this defines a cochain complex and we can define its cohomology as Hn(G,M) = Zn(G,M)/Bn(G,M) (5.2.29) where { Zn(G,M) := ker(dn+1) Bn(G,M) := im(dn) if n 1. (5.2.30) 0 if = 0 n In what follows we will denote the group action on Hn(G,M) also in the same additive notation that we used for Cn(G,M). This notation makes sense because of the property that for any 1, 2 Zn(G, M) we have that 1 + 2Hn(G,M) = 1Hn(G,M) + 2Hn(G,M) . Remark 5.2.4. In [16], they argue that this definition of group cohomology is only the right approach for discrete groups. When we want to generalize this to any continuous group that has a well defined Haar measure we additionally have to impose that the cochains are measurable. Group cohomology with measurable cochains is sometimes called Borel Group cohomology. We believe that it should be possible to construct a Borel Group cohomology group element from SPT states protected by any locally compact Lie group. However this is beyond the scope of this paper. 14So in particular when we write g1(g2, , gn) for any Cn1(G, M) we will sometimes identify it simply with (g2, , gn). L R gL gR Figure 5.1: These figures indicate the support area of the different automorphisms in a particular decomposition of the QAut. The angle needs to be smaller then or equal to what was indicated here so that the and the g (possibly after widening by one site) commute. 5.3 Results This section will contain three different parts. First we discuss the main result starting from some rather abstract assumptions. In the second part we present the claim that these assumptions are implied by some more natural assumptions relating to short range entanglement. In the last part of the section we compare our assumptions to those made in [48]. 5.3.1 Statement of the result in terms of Q-automorphisms Similarly what was done in [48], we will define an index on the space of states that can be disentangled by a Q-automorphism. This class of automorphisms is defined as: Definition 5.3.1. Take Aut(A). For P (AL0 ), any a one dimensional G-invariant and translation invariant state satisfying assumption 5.3.3, the state as defined in 5.2.1 satisfies IndexA1dLt0r,aUns() = IndexA2,tUrans(). (5.3.18) iii. This index is a group homomorphism under the stacking operator by which we mean that IndexA22tr,UansU (1 stack 2) = IndexA2,tUrans(1) + IndexA2,tUrans(2). (5.3.19) iv. The index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space by which we mean that for any on site unitary V we get that IndexA2,tAradn(sV )(U)( iV ) = IndexA2,tUrans (). (5.3.20) Proof. This statement is proven in subsection 5.5.8. 5.3.2 SRE implies previous assumptions The assumptions in the previous subsection are rather technical. In this section we show that these assumptions are strictly weaker than assumptions that are more natural. The assumptions on the states will now be that they are short range entangled (see definition 5.2.2). We will use the exact same definition (with the same F-function) for states over the quasi local C-algebra over Z, AL0. We are now ready to show that SRE implies the previous assumptions. Lemma 5.3.8. Take P (A) a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant then it satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. See subsection 5.4.9. Lemma 5.3.9. Any G-invariant SRE state P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.3. Proof. See subsection 5.4.9. These two results imply that to any G-invariant translation invariant SRE state I can associate a consistent LGA invariant H 3(G, T) H 2(G, T)-valued SPT index. The first index is the index when there are no translations and the last index is the one from theorem 5.3.4. Lemma 5.3.10. Let be a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant in two directions then it satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. See subsection 5.5.9. Lemma 5.3.11. Any G-invariant, translation invariant SRE state P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.6. Proof. Trivially follows from lemma 5.3.9. This shows that if a G-invariant SRE state is translation invariant in two directions I can find a consistent LGA invariant H3(G,T) H2(G,T) H2(G,T)H1(G,T) valued SPT index. The first index is again the index when there are no translations, the second and third index are given by Index() and Index( ) (5.3.21) where was the rotation automorphism and Index was defined in theorem 5.3.4. Finally the H1(G,T)-valued index is defined in theorem 5.3.7. We now only have to show that there is no additional H1(G,T)-valued index: Lemma 5.3.12. Let be the automorphism that rotates every element of the C algebra by 90 degrees then IndexA2,tUrans() = IndexA2,tUrans( ). (5.3.22) Proof. This is proven in subsection 5.5.5. Now all that is left to show is that the indices defined here are constant on the stable equivalence classes introduced in the introduction and later on clarified in subsection 5.2.4. To this end let , 1, 2 and 3 be the stable equivalence classes without translation symmetry, with only the translation symmetry, with only the translation symmetry and with both the and translation symmetry respectively. We now show the following lemma: Lemma 5.3.13. Take (1, U1) and (2, U2) elements of S0 (see subsection 5.2.4) for algebras A1 and A2. The following three statements now hold true: i. If 1, U1 = 2, U2 then IndexAno1,tUra1ns(1) = IndexAno2,tUra2ns(2) (5.3.23) where Indexno trans is the SPT index introduced in [48] (see subsection 5.3.3 for why this is well defined in this context). ii. If additionally (1, U1), (2, U2) S1 and 1, U11 = 2, U21 then IndexA1,U1(1) = IndexA2,U2(2) (5.3.24) where Index is the index introduced in theorem 5.3.4. iii. If additionally (1, U1), (2, U2) S2 and 1, U12 = 2, U22 then IndexA1,U1(1 ) = IndexA2,U2(2 ) (5.3.25) where was the rotation automorphism. iv. If additionally (1, U1), (2, U2) S3 and 1, U13 = 2, U23 then IndexA21tr,Uan1s(1) = IndexA22tr,Uan2s(2) (5.3.26) where Index2 trans is the index introduced in theorem 5.3.7. Proof. This is shown in appendix B.6. 5.3.3 Comparison with [48] The first thing we would like to remark is that in [48], a different equivalence class on states is used. First of all the set of states considered is a priori different. Namely, for any state P (A), we define two different conditions i. There exists a PSL16 such that is the unique gapped groundstate of . ii. is an SRE state. 16This is defined in [48] but it essentially means bounded interaction that is connected to a trivial (without overlapping terms) interaction. However in theorem 5.1 of [48] it is proven that the first item implies the second item. If one then looks at the definition of the index there, one could as well have started from the second condition. This is precisely what we did in this paper. As a side note, one should also be able to prove that the second item implies the first item by using theorem D.5 of [48] with Kt the disentangler and a gapped interaction that has the product state as its groundstate. However, we wont work this out explicitly in this paper. When we add the group, the story changes considerably. Let us define the two different equivalence classes. To this end, let 1 and 2 be two (pure) G-invariant states that are unique gapped groundstates of 0 and 1 PSL, respectively. The following two conditions define different equivalence classes: i. There exists a G-invariant, bounded path of gapped interactions () (see [48] for precise definitions) such that 1 and 2 are unique gapped groundstates of (0) and (1) respectively. ii. There exists a G-invariant LGA, 0;1 such that 1 0H;1 = 2. A priori those two conditions are not equivalent. However in [48] it is proven that, the first equivalence implies the second one. The proof that equivalent states have the same index only uses the second condition. This means that one could also have taken the second equivalence condition as the starting point. This is exactly what we do in this paper. One should also be able to show that the second condition implies the first one using a similar construction as in the above remark without the group and averaging the resulting interaction over the group (where one then has to use that a finite group has a normalised Haar measure). There where two things that are in theorems 5.3.4 and 5.3.7 but where not discussed in [48]. This is the part that the index is a group homomorphism under stacking and the part that the index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space. However, on inspection of the arguments used in subsections 5.4.6 and 5.4.7 one can conclude that these also hold for the H3-valued index. All in all we have provided a proof that the work done in [48] also implies the following theorem: Theorem 5.3.14. For any A satisfying the construction from section 5.2.1 and any choice of on site group action U hom(G,U(Cd)), there exists a map IndexAno,Utrans : { P(A)| is SRE and G-invariant} H3(G,T) (5.3.27) that is well defined (doesnt depend on the choice of disentangler). This map will satisfy: i. For any G invariant family of interactions BF ([0, 1]) we have that IndexAno,Utrans() = IndexAno,Utrans( 0;1). (5.3.28) ii. This index is a group homomorphism under the stacking operator by which we mean that IndexAno2,tUranUs (1 stack 2) = IndexAno,Utrans(1) + IndexAno,Utrans(2). (5.3.29) iii. The index is independent on the choice of basis for the on site Hilbert space by which we mean that for any on site unitary V we get that IndexAno,Atdra(nVs)(U)( iV ) = IndexAno,Utrans(). (5.3.30) 5.4 The H2(G, T)-valued index In this section we will define the H 2 (G, T)-valued index starting from assumption 5.3.2. We will restate this assumption here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.2. Let P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism QAut1(A) and a product state 0 P(A) satisfying = 0 . ii. such that there exists a ]0, /2[ for which there exists a map : G Aut(A) : g g satisfying g = g = Ad(Vg,2) Lg gR gU for some Vg,2 U(A), gL Aut(ACL) and Rg Aut(ACR). iii. translation invariant ( = ). (5.3.2) (5.3.3) (5.3.4) THE H2(G, T)-VALUED INDEXIn what follows, we will first fix certain objects to define the index and then in section 5.4.3 we will show that it is independent of all these choices. Fix an 0 and an . Fix (H0 = HL HR, 0 = L R, 0) a GNS triple (see theorem B.1.1) of 0 where ( {L, R}) : A B(H) is a GNS representation of the restriction of 0 to . Remark 5.4.4. The main reason for the introduction of the ConeW (0, ) andwhen translated. We start our construction by taking a state P (AL0 ) that satisfies assumption 5.3.3. We restate this assumption here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.3. Take P(AL0) such that i. g = . ii. there exist automorphisms L Aut(AL0L), R Aut(AL0R) and a summable operator b U(AL0) such that 0 = Ad(b) L R (5.3.5) is a product state. Lemma 5.4.16. This satisfies the split property. (HL HR, L L R R, L R(b)L R) is a GNS triple of . This Proof. Take (HL HR, L R, L R) a GNS triple of 0. By construction concludes the proof that satisfies the split property. By the result of [47] this implies that has a well defined 1d SPT index (see appendix B.8). For any j and n take Z N Lj := {(x, y) Z2|y = j} Lnj := {(x, y) Z2|y = j, x [n, n]} (5.4.69) L<j := {(x, y) Z2|y < j} L>j := {(x, y) Z2|y > j}. (5.4.70) We introduce some additional notation, for any automorphism Aut(AL0 ) we define (,j) := j j. (5.4.71) We will now define the infinite tensor product state. Definition 5.4.17. Take P(AL0) arbitrary. There exists a unique state satisfying that for any i we have that for any A ALi and B ALci Z (A B) = j(A)(B). (5.4.72) Proof. We have that: Lemma 5.4.18. Let be the infinite tensor product of a state that satisfies assumption 5.3.3 then satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. The proof is in lemma B.3.1. This shows that has a well defined 2d translation index. We will now show that Index() = Index1d(). We now fix a GNS triple of 0 that is of the form H0 = H, , 0 = ,,0 = , {L,R} {L,R} {L,R} {L>1,L1,L<1} {L>1,L1,L<1} {L>1,L1,L<1} (5.4.74) where the , : A B(H,) are all irreducible representations. Remark 5.4.19. We clearly have (by construction) that L1,L L|L1 L1,R R|L1 (5.4.75) is a GNS representation of . This implies that if we take any kR : G U(HL1,R) such that Ad(kR(g)) L1,R R|L1 = L1,R R|L1 gL1R then there exists a 2 cochain C satisfying that (5.4.76) kR(g)kR(h)kR(gh)1 = C(g, h)1HL1,R (5.4.77) and that the equivalence class this cochain is in, is given by Index1d(). Let k : G U(HL1) be the unique operator that satisfies Ad(kg) L1 = L1 |L1 gL1 1|L1 kgL1 = L1. (5.4.78) Similarly, let w : G U(HL>1,L HL>1,R) be the unique operator such that Ad(wg) L>1 = L>1 |L>1 gi(U) 1|L>1 wgL>1 = L>1. (5.4.79) Clearly both functions are (linear) representation of the group. Now define Wg = 0(V1)(wg 1HL1 1HL<1 )0(V1). (5.4.80) This operator valued function is also a linear representation and satisfies thewe get that WgWhWgh1 = 1H0. This implies that we can take u(g,h) = conditions indicated in lemma 5.4.6. Since Wg is a linear representation1 H, (for any {L,R}). All that is now left is to calculate Kg U (H ). We get that {L>1,L1,L<1} Kg = vWgvWg (5.4.81) = v0(V1)(wg 1HL1 1HL<1 )0(V1)vWg (5.4.82) = 0(V1)(wg 1HL1 1HL<1 )0(V1)Wg. (5.4.83) Notice however that (wg 1HL1 1HL<1 ) and wg kg 1HL<1 both leave the cyclic vector invariant and have the same adjoint action on the GNS representation. By the uniqueness of such operators we get that Kg = 0(V1)(wg kg 1HL<1)0(V1)Wg. (5.4.84) Using the adjoint of equation (5.4.80) this gives Kg = 0(V1)(1HL>1 kg 1HL<1)0(V1) (5.4.85) = 1HL>1 L1(b)kgL1(b) 1HL<1 (5.4.86) where = 0(V1)v0(V1). Noticethatwehave(byconstruction)thatg,hG and these kg will satisfy what was written in remark 5.4.19. Define Kg = [Kg 1HZ2/ , Wh] = 0. (5.4.88) We now get (using this equation and the fact that Wg is a representation) KgRWgKhRWhWgh(KgRh)WghWhWguR(g, h) (5.4.89) = WgWhWghKgRKhR(KgRh) (5.4.90) = kRgkhR(kgRh) 1HL>1, 1HL<1, and by remark 5.4.19 this gives that C(g, h) = C(g, h). (5.4.91) 5.4.5 Index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms The goal of this section is now to show that the index we constructed is invariant under locally generated automorphisms (the final proof of this statement is under theorem 5.4.26). To this end let H BF ([0, 1]) be G-invariant, translation invariant (in the vertical direction) one parameter family of interactions. Define furthermore for notational simplicity in this section Hsplit = HL + HR (with HL and HR the restrictions of H as defined in 5.2.3). Clearly we have that tH;ssplit = tH;sL tH;sR and we still have that tH;ssplit = tH;ssplit (just like we have for H ). For the remainder of the section we will use a decomposition using the following lemma: U0;1 Aut(AW(C)cU) and D0;1 Aut(AW(C)cD), both commuting with Lemma 5.4.20. Take 0 < < /2 and Aut(AW(C)c). This is shown after lemma B.11.1. 5.4.6 Stacking in the H2(G,T)-valued index Take A a quasi local C algebra on a two dimensional lattice and take U hom(G,U(Cd)) an on site group action arbitrary. Let 1,2 { P(A)| satisfies assumption 5.3.2} be two states. The goal of this section is to prove that (5.4.122) IndexA2,UU (1 stack 2) = IndexA,U (1) + IndexA,U (2). (5.4.123) Let 0i that and 0;1i (for all i {1, 2}) be product states and disentanglers satisfying i = 0i 0;i1. (5.4.124) Let (H0i, 0i, 0i) be GNS triples for the 0i. Clearly (H01 H02, 01 02, 01 02) is a GNS triple for 01 stack 02. The following lemma now holds: (5.4.125) (5.4.126) Lemma 5.4.27. Let Wg,i, ui(g, h), Kg,i and vi be operators belonging to i then Wg,1 Wg,2, u1(g, h) u2(g, h), Kg,1 Kg,2 and v1 v2 are operators belonging to 1 stack 2. Proof. To show this we simply have to apply the adjoint action of these operators on 01 02 and see that these are indeed implementations of the right automorphisms. This is so by construction. We are now ready to provide a proof of equation 5.4.123. We have C(g, h) = (KgR,1 KgR,2)Ad(Wg,1 Wg,2)((KhR,1 KhR,2)Ad((Wh,1 Wh,2)(Wgh,1 Wgh,2))((KRgh,1 KgRh,2))) (uR1(g, h) uR2(g, h))v(uR1(g, h) uR2(g, h))v = C1(g, h)C2(g, h) (5.4.127) concluding the proof. Remark 5.4.28. Clearly the same argument can be used to argue that the H3-valued index is invariant under stacking. 5.4.7 The H2-valued index is invariant of choice of basis of on site Hilbert space Let V U(Cd) be a unitary operator on the on site Hilbert space and take iV as defined in subsection 5.2.1. In this subsection we will prove that IndexA,Ad(V ) (U)(, iV1 g iV , iV1 g iV , iV1 0 iV , iV1 iV , iV , 0 iV ) = IndexA,U(,g,g,0,,,0). We do this by proving the following lemma: Lemma 5.4.29. Let Wg,uR(g,h),KgR be operators belonging to IndexA,U(,g,g,0,,,0) (5.4.128) (5.4.129) (5.4.130) for a GNS triple for 0, (H0, 0, 0) then Wg, uR(g, h), KgR are also operators belonging to IndexA,Ad(V )(U)(, iV1 g iV , iV1 g iV , iV1 0 iV , iV1 iV , iV , 0 iV ) (5.4.131) for the GNS triple for 0 iV given by (H0, 0 iV , 0). Proof. To show this, we merely have to observe that for any x U(H0) satisfying that Ad(x) 0 0 = 0 0 (5.4.132) for some Aut(A) we get that Ad(x) 0 iV iV1 0 iV iV1 iV = 0 iV iV1 0 iV iV1 iV iV1 iV (5.4.133) concluding the proof. Clearly the above lemma implies that the H2-valued index is invariant under the desired transformation. Remark 5.4.30. Clearly the same argument can be used to argue that the H3-valued index is invariant under the same transformation. 5.4.8 Proof of theorem 5.3.4 In this section we summarise the proof of theorem 5.3.4: Proof. The 2-cochain was defined in subsection 5.4.2. The proof that it wasnt dependent on any of the choices made in assumption 5.3.2 was done in subsection 5.4.3. The first item in the list concerning the invariance under locally generated automorphisms was shown in subsection 5.4.5. The proof of the second item concerning the relation between the 1d SPT index and the 2d translation SPT index is done in subsection 5.4.4. The proof of the third item concerning the stacking is done in subsection 5.4.6. The proof of the last item concerning a change of basis of the on site Hilbert space is done in subsection 5.4.7. This concludes the proof. gL gR (-1,-1) Figure 5.3: This figure indicates the support area of the different automorphisms when there are two translation directions. The angle still has to be smaller then or equal to what was indicated here so that the and the g commute but now we must be able to do both a horizontal and a vertical widening of the support of g. Also the coordinate (1, 1) which will be of particular interest is indicated. 5.4.9 Proof of lemma 5.3.8 and lemma 5.3.9 We will provide a proof of lemma 5.3.8 which we state here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.8. Take P (A) a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant then it satisfies assumption 5.3.2. Proof. Let 0;1 be the disentangler with BF([0,1]) (for some 0 < < 1) a one parameter family of interactions. By lemma B.10.4 part 5 (which is just a slight modification of section 5 from [48]) we have that 0;1 SQAut1(A) (by which we mean the definition of SQAut as presented in appendix B.10.1, not the one in [48]) since SQAut1(A) QAut1(A) this implies that 0;1 QAut1(A). The existence of the g was done in [48] section 3, where one has to use the fact that 0;1 is also an SQAut in the definition by [48]. This concludes the proof that assumption 5.3.2 is satisfied. We will now prove lemma 5.3.9 that we restate here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.9. Any G-invariant SRE state P (AL0 ) satisfies assumption 5.3.3. Proof. The proof simply uses lemma B.9.1. 5.5 The H1(G,T)-valued index In this section we discuss translation invariance not just in the vertical direction but in two directions simultaneously. Let Aut(A) be the automorphism that translates the lattice to the right by one site. Let Aut(A) be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90 clockwise. There is a relation between these automorphisms. Specifically, the automorphism that translated the lattice upwards by one site can now be written as = 1 . We now let our state satisfy assumption 5.3.5. We will restate this assumption here forconvenience Assumption 5.3.5. Let P(A) be i. such that there exists an automorphism QAut1(A) and a product state 0 P(A) satisfying = 0 . (5.3.11) ii. such that there exists a ]0, /2[ for which there exists a map : G Aut(A) : g g (5.3.12) satisfying g = g = Ad(Vg,2) Lg gR gU (5.3.13) for some Vg,2 U(A), gL Aut(A1(CL)) and gR Aut(A(CR)). iii. translation invariant in both directions = = . (5.3.14) For an overview of the supports see figure 5.3. In this section we will need a stronger version of the cone operators (from definition 5.4.2): Definition 5.5.1. Take 0 < < /2 and L Aut(AL) and R Aut(AR). Take {L, R} and x U(H) 1HZ2/ then we say that x is a cone operator on ()19 (or in short x Cone()(0, )) if and only if there exists a Aut(AW((C))) such that Ad(x) 0 0 = 0 0 . (5.5.1) Cone()(0, ) is a subgroup of U(H) 1Z2/ If additionally . Aut(A(C)) we will say that x ConeW()(0, ). 19Where we define L := 1 and R := . Similarly as before we will also need the generalisation of this definition: Definition 5.5.2. Take 0 < < /2, L Aut(AL), R Aut(AR) and Aut(AW(C)c). Take {L, R} and take x U(H0) then we say that x is an inner after cone operator on () (or in short x IAC()(0, , )) if there exists an A U(A()) and a y Cone()(0, ) such that x = 0 0 (A)y. (5.5.2) 5.5.1 Definition of the index First notice that since this assumption is strictly stronger then the assumption in 5.3.2 we can still define all the objects we did before. So in what follows fix a v U(H0), Wg U(H0), u(g,h) ConeW()(0,) and Kg Cone()(0,) (for every g,h G) and then later on we will show independence on the choice of these objects. We remind the reader of some equalities from section 5.4 Ad(v) 0 0 = 0 0 Ad(Wg) 0 0 = 0 0 g gU Ad(u(g, h)) = g gU h (gU )1 (gh)1 (5.5.3) (5.5.4) (5.5.5) uL(g, h) uR(g, h) = WgWhWgh1 (5.5.6) Ad(KgR) 0 0 = 0 0 1 gR gRU (gRU)1 (gR)1. (5.5.7) In what follows, we will need the vertical analogue of the v. We define the horizontal translation operator: Lemma 5.5.3. There exists a unique w U(H0) such that Ad(w) 0 = 0 0 1 01 and 0(V1)w0(V1)0 = 0. (5.5.8) Proof. Analogous to the proof of 5.4.1. We can use these objects to define bg: Lemma 5.5.4. There exist a bLg ConeW1(L)(0, ) and a bRg ConeWR (0, ) (both unique up to an exchange of a Gdependent phase) satisfying that wWgwWg = bg := bLg bRg. (5.5.9) It will satisfy Ad bg 1HZ2/ 0 0 = 0 0 1 g (g)1. ( ) (5.5.10) Proof. It is easy enough to show that Ad(wWgwWg) 0 = 0 (L 1 gL (gL)1 L1) (R 1 Rg (Rg)1 R1). (5.5.11) To do this one only has to use that gU commutes with . By lemma B.1.3 the result now follows. Lemma 5.5.5. There exists an : G U(1) satisfying vbRgvhgKgR(bRg) = (g)wKgRw where hg := 0 0 (U(1,1)(g)). Proof. The proof is presented after B.2.2. We have that hg IACL(, 0, ). On top of that we also have that Lemma 5.5.6. For all g, h G we have that [hg,Wh] = 0 [hg,bLh] = 0. (5.5.12) (5.5.13) (5.5.14) Proof. We have that (see figure 5.3) Ad(Wh)(hg) = 0 0 h hU(U(1,1)(g)) (5.5.15) = 0 0 (U(1,1)(g)) = hg (5.5.16) concluding the proof of the first item. The second proof is analogous. Finally before we can show that the is a U (1) representation we need to prove an analogue of the equation in the 2-cochain lemma 5.4.9: Lemma 5.5.7. The equality Ad bRgWgbRhWhWgh(bRgh)WghWhWguR(g, h) 0 = Ad(wuR(g, h)w) 0 ( ) (5.5.17) holds. Proof. The proof is almost completely analogous to the proof of 5.4.9. We first start by showing that Ad bgWgbhWhWgh(bgh)WghWhWguL(g, h) uR(g, h) 0 = Ad(wuR(g, h) uR(g, h)w) 0 ( ) (5.5.18) holds. This part is completely the same. The only difference is now that to prove that bgWgbhWhWgh(bgh)WghWhWg (5.5.19) is split one needs to use the new (shifted) support of g. Using this we can show that: Lemma 5.5.8. The defined previously is a U(1)-representation. Proof. Take the definition of the 2-cochain (lemma 5.4.9) KgRWgKhRWhWgh(KgRh)WghWhWguR(g,h) = C(g,h)vuR(g,h)v. (5.5.20) Clearly this equation is invariant under the substitution KgR wKgRw Wg wWgw uR(g,h) wuR(g,h)w. (5.5.21) If we now also show that it is invariant under the substitution KgR vbRgvhgKgR(bRg) Wg wWgw uR(g,h) wuR(g,h)w (5.5.22) then we get using the definition of that C(g,h) = C(g,h)(g()gh()h) (5.5.23) which would clearly conclude the proof. This invariance is proven after lemma B.7.3. Definition 5.5.9. Let be the U (1)-representation defined in lemma 5.5.5. Take hom(G, T) such that (g) = exp(i(g)). We define the 2 translation index as IndexA2t,Urans(, g, g, 0, , , 0) := H1(G, T) (5.5.24) and (as advertised) it is only a function of the automorphisms (and the product state) not on the choice of the GNS triple of 0 or on the choice of phases in Wg, uL(g, h), uR(g, h), v, w, KgL, KgR, bLg and bRg.20 20It is however explicitly dependent on the on site group action U, and not only Ad(U). Proof. Clearly the construction is invariant under the choice of GNS triple since this simply amounts to an adjoint action by some unitary on every operator. The proof that it is independent of the choice of phases is just as trivial. One can also define this index starting from operators acting on the left. As the following lemma shows this gives us the opposite index (the complex conjugate of the U (1)-representation): Lemma 5.5.10. Define (g) such that vbLgvhgKgL(bLg) = (g)wKgLw (5.5.25) then (g)(g) = 1. Proof. By multiplying the left hand side of equation (5.5.25) with the left hand side of equation (5.5.12) we obtain vbgvKgbg = vbgvvWgvWgbg = wvWgvWgw = wKgw whereas by multiplying the right hand sides we obtain = (g)(g)wKgw. These two results can only be consistent if the lemma holds. (5.5.26) (5.5.27) (5.5.28) (5.5.29) 5.5.2 The H1(G, T)-valued index is invariant under choices In this section we will show that the index is only dependent on and not on the choices of our automorphisms nor on 0. On this last item we remark: Remark 5.5.11. A product state can have a non-trivial H1(G,T) index and the index is not defined relative to 0 so in particular IndexA2t,Urans(,gU,Id,Id,Id,0,0) (5.5.30) can still be non-trivial. In fact in this case we get (g) = 0(U(1,1)(g)). To show this, notice that we can take bg = 1H and we can choose KgR so that it leaves the cyclic vector of 0, 0 invariant. Applying the definition of the index on this cyclic vector then gives us hg0 = (g)0. This obviously implies that 0, hg0 = (g)0, 0 giving us indeed the advertised equation. We will now show independence of and its decomposition. Lemma 5.5.12. Take 01, 02 P(A) product states and 1, 2 Aut(A) such that 01 1 = 02 2 = . (5.5.31) Let V11, V12 U(A), L/R,1, L/R,2 Aut(AL/R and 1, 2 Aut(A ) ) be such that W(C)c 1 = Ad(V11) 01 1 2 = Ad(V12) 02 2 (5.5.32) with 0,i = L,i R,i, then IndexA2t,Urans(, g, g, 0,1, 1, , 01) = Index2At,rUans(, g, g, 0,2, 2, , 02). (5.5.33) Proof. We will first prove the result in the case that 0 = 01 = 02 and then generalise this result. Since 0 2 11 = 0 there exists a x U(H0) such that 0 2 11 = Ad(x) 0. Now define x U(H0) to be x := 0(V12)x0(V11) then 0 02 2 = Ad(x) 0 01 1. (5.5.34) (5.5.35) (5.5.36) Let v, w, Kg and bg be operators belonging to the first choice then by construction xvx, xwx, xKgx and xbgx are operators belonging to the second choice. Since the index is invariant under this substitution this concludes the proof in the case that 0 = 01 = 02. Now suppose that 01 02. Since they are both product states there exists a Aut(A) satisfying 02 = 01 that is of the form = L R. We now have IndexA2t,Urans(, g, g, 0,2, 2, , 02) = IndexA2t,Urans(, g, g, 0,2, 2, , 01 ) (5.5.37) = IndexA2t,Urans(, g, g, 0,2, 2, , 01) (5.5.38) concluding the proof. In what follows we will need that the index is invariant under the following transformation: Lemma 5.5.13. Take 0, , 0, and g as usual, take v, w, Wg,1, u,1(g, h), Kg,1 and bg,1 operators corresponding to these automorphisms and take g IAC()(0, , ) (for all {L, R} and all g G). Define Wg,2 := gWg,1 (5.5.39) u,2(g, h) := gWg,1hWg,1u,1(g, h)(gh) (5.5.40) Kg,2 := vgvKg,1(g) (5.5.41) bg,2 := wgwbg,1(g) (5.5.42) then the index of v, w, Wg,1, u,1(g, h), Kg,1, hg and bg,1 is equal to the index of v, w, Wg,2, u,2(g, h), hg, Kg,2 and bg,2. The one cochain also remains unchanged. Proof. The proof is given after lemma B.7.4. We will now show that the index is independent on the choice of g and its decomposition. Lemma 5.5.14. Take g,1, g,2 Aut(A), Vg,21, Vg,22 U(A), Lg,1, gL,2 Aut(AL(CL) and Rg,1, gR,2 Aut(AR(CR) such that there exist ) ) Vg,21,Vg,22 U(A) satisfying g,1 = Ad(Vg,21) g,1 gU g,2 = Ad(Vg,22) g,2 gU (5.5.43) and g,1 = g,2 = (5.5.44) then Index2 trans(, g,1, g,1, 0, , , 0) = Index2 trans(, g,2, g,2, 0, , , 0). Now using lemma 5.5.13 concludes the proof. Lemma 5.5.15. The index is independent of the choice of angle . Proof. After what was done so far this result is trivial. Due to all these considerations we will write this index as IndexA2,tUrans() from here on onward. 5.5.3 Example (consistency with conjecture 5.1.3) This example will be very similar to what was done in section 5.4.4. In this case however we will require that the translation morphism acts as an automorphism on the C algebra ALi (for all i) and that our one dimensional state is invariant under this automorphism. We will need assumption 5.3.6 which we restate here for convenience: Assumption 5.3.6. Take P (AL0 ) such that i. g = . ii. there exist automorphisms L Aut(AL0L), R Aut(AL0R) and a summable (see subsection 5.2.1 for the definition) operator b U(AL0 ) such that 0 = Ad(b) L R (5.3.15) is a product state. iii. = . Since this state satisfies the split property (see lemma 5.4.16) we can define an H1(G, T) valued index for it (see appendix B.8). Now we will take again the infinite tensor product (see definition 5.4.17) of such states then we get: Lemma 5.5.16. Let be the infinite tensor product of a state that satisfies assumption 5.3.6 then satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. The proof of this lemma is given in lemma B.3.2. This shows that indeed has a well defined H1(G, T) index. We will now show that Index2 trans() = Index1d trans(). Just like in section 5.4.4, we fix a GNS triple of 0 that is of the form H0 H, , 0 = ,,0 = = , {L,R} {L,R} {L,R} {L>1,L1,L<1} {L>1,L1,L<1} {L>1,L1,L<1} (5.5.56) where the , : A B(H,) are all irreducible representations. Remark 5.5.17. We clearly have (by construction) that L1,L L|L1 L1,R R|L1 (5.5.57) is a GNS representation of . This implies that if we take any kR : G HL1,R such that Ad(kR(g)) L1,R R|L1 = L1,R R|L1 gL1R (5.5.58) and wL1 to be such that Ad(wL1) L1,L L1,R = L1,L L1,R (5.5.59) then there exists a U(1) representation satisfying that (L1,L(U(1,1)(g)) 1HL1,R)(1HL1,L kR(g)) = (g)wL1(1HL1,L kR(g))wL1 (5.5.60) and that it is given by Index1d trans(). Just like in section 5.4.4, let k : G U (HL1 ) be the unique operator that satisfies Ad(kg) L1 = L1 |L1 gL1 1|L1 kgL1 = L1. (5.5.67) 5.5.4 The H1(G,T)-valued index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms The goal of this section is to show that the index we constructed is invariant under locally generated automorphisms. To this end let H BF([0,1]) be a G-invariant, translation invariant (in both directions) one parameter family of interactions. In the rest of this section we will define (for notational simplicity) Hsplit := H1(L) + H(R). Clearly, this Hsplit is translation invariant in the vertical direction but not in the horizontal direction. The proof is very similar to what was done in theorem 5.4.26 but with some notable differences. We first need a different version of lemma 5.4.20 (in fact it is almost completely identical only the definition of Hsplit is now slightly different) and use this to define some objects used in the rest of the section: Lemma 5.5.18. (5.5.109) First we will show that this transformation indeed leaves the index invariant, then we will show that these operators indeed belong to 0H;1. (5.5.114) This shows that the index is invariant under the 1 and Rg part (simultaneously). The fact that the index is invariant under the 1(g) part is now completely equivalent to the proof of lemma 5.5.13. The fact that the index remains unchanged by the Ad(0(A1)) transformation is trivial. This concludes this part of the proof. Now we only need to show that these operators indeed belong to 0H;1. This is proven in lemma B.11.2. 5.5.5 The H1(G,T)-valued index is invariant under rotations by 90 Take P (A) { is an SRE state, } g , = = and = (5.5.115) arbitrary and let be the automorphism that rotates the lattice by 90. Proof. The existence of the v, w, KgR and bRg is due to the fact that 0;1 QAut1(A). This follows from lemma B.10.4 and from the fact that SQAut1(A) QAut1(A).
