The following equalities hold [hg,wbUgw] = 0 (5.5.140) [wbUgw,vbRgv] = 0 (5.5.141) [hg,vbRgv] = 0 (5.5.142) [KgR,bUg] = 0 (5.5.143) [hg,KgR] = 0 (5.5.144) [KgR,vKgUv] = 0 (5.5.145) Proof. All of the above commute as automorphisms on the C algebra, we now have to show that the operators in the GNS space commute as well. First we will start by proving equations (5.5.140), (5.5.142) and (5.5.144). For any operator x U(H0) satisfying that there exists a Aut(A) such that Ad(x) 0 0;1 = 0 0;1 (5.5.146) we get that Ad(x)(hg) = 0 0;1 (U(1,1)(g)). (5.5.147) Applying this to these equations gives the desired result. To show the remaining equations decompose 0 and 0;1 as 0;1 = Ad(B) 0;i1 4 0 = 4 0,i (5.5.148) i=1 i=1 where the 0,i are irreducible representations in Ai, the areas i are indicated in figure 5.4 and the have support in the areas shaded red. This shows that up to some inner automorphisms the operators with an R on top act on different parts of the decomposition of 0 then the operators with a U on top do. Combining this with lemma B.1.3 concludes the proof. Lemma 5.5.32. (g) = (g). Proof. We will work out the expression hgvbRgvwbUgwKgRKgUXg (5.5.149) in two different ways. On the one hand we will use (5.5.141) together with equation (5.5.140) to get (5.5.149) = wbUgwhgvbRgvKgRKgUXg. Now using equation (5.5.130) we get (5.5.149) = (g)wbUgwwKgRwbRgKgUXg = (g)wbUgKgRXgw = (g)wvXgvw (5.5.150) (5.5.151) (5.5.152) (5.5.153) where weve used equation (5.5.132) in the first equality and (5.5.131) in the second equality. On the other hand, starting with equation (5.5.142), (5.5.143) and (5.5.144) gives (5.5.149) = vbRgvhgwbUgwKgRKgUXg = vbRgvKgRhgwbUgwKgUXg. (5.5.154) (5.5.155) Now using equation (5.5.133) we get (5.5.149) = (g)vbRgvKgRvKgUvbUgXg = (g)vbRgvvKgUvbUgKgRXg = (g)vbRgvvKgUvvXgv = (g)vwXgwv (5.5.156) (5.5.157) (5.5.158) (5.5.159) where weve used equation (5.5.145) and (5.5.143) in the first equality, equation (5.5.131) in the second equality and equation (5.5.132) in the last equality. These two results can only be consistent if (g) = (g) for all g G. 5.5.6 Stacking in the H1(G,T)-valued index Take A a quasi local C algebra on a two dimensional lattice and take U(g) an on site group action arbitrary. Let 1, 2 { P(A)| satisfies assumption 5.3.5} (5.5.160) be two states. The goal of this section is to prove that IndexA22tr,Uan(sg)U(g)(1 stack 2) = IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(1)IndexA2,tUra(ngs)(2). (5.5.161) The proof of this is completely analogous to what was in section 5.4.6. 5.5.7 The H1-valued index is invariant of choice of basis of on site Hilbert space Let V U(Cd) be a unitary operator on the on site Hilbert space and take iV as defined in subsection 5.2.1. In this subsection we will prove that A,Ad(V )(U) Index2 trans (, iV1 g iV , iV1 g iV , iV1 0 iV , iV1 iV , iV , 0 iV ) (5.5.162) = IndexA2,tUrans(, g, g, 0, , , 0). (5.5.163) The proof is completely analogous to the proof presented in subsection 5.4.7. 5.5.8 Proof of theorem 5.3.7 In this section we summarise the proof of theorem 5.3.7: Proof. The 2-cochain was defined in subsection 5.5.1. The proof that it wasnt dependent on any of the choices made in assumption 5.3.5 was done in subsection 5.5.2. The first item in the list concerning the invariance under locally generated automorphisms was shown in subsection 5.5.4. The proof of the second item concerning the relation between the 1d SPT index and the 2d translation SPT index is done in subsection 5.5.3. The proof of the third item concerning the stacking is done in subsection 5.5.6. The proof of the last item concerning a change of basis of the on site Hilbert space is done in subsection 5.5.7. This concludes the proof. 5.5.9 Proof of lemma 5.3.10 In this subsection we prove lemma 5.3.10 which we restate here for convenience: Lemma 5.3.10. Let be a short range entangled state that is G-invariant and translation invariant in two directions then it satisfies assumption 5.3.5. Proof. Completely analogous to the proof of lemma 5.3.8 except that the support area of the g automorphism has become smaller. To deal with this, replace the SQAut(A) in theorem 3.1 of [48] by SQAut2(A) (see definition B.10.8) and observe that the resulting g has the right support. Chapter 6 Conclusion We have shown how the mathematical tools in section 3 can be used to produce multiple SPT indices and that these indices are robust and in some cases complete. In chapter 4 we had a quasi-local C-algebra over Z. We defined to concept of G-loops in definition ?? and defined the concept of stable G-homotopy in definition ??. We then produced an H1(G, T)-valued index for G-loops which we called the charge pumping index. We then showed that two G-loops are stably homotopic if and only if they had the same index. We denoted this result in theorem 4.3.8. In chapter 5 we had a quasi-local C-algebra over Z2. We defined the concept of SRE in definition 5.2.2 and defined an on site symmetry and two translation symmetries. We defined the sets S0, S1, S2 and S3 as the subsets of SRE states that satisfied some symmetry. We added an equivalence relation on these sets in definition 5.2.3. We then defined an H2(G,T)-valued index for every translation symmetry and an H1(G,T)-valued index in the case where there are two translation symmetries. Finally, we showed that the index is invariant under the choice of representative in the stable equivalence relation. This we formulated in lemma 5.3.13. There is an endless amount of further research that could be conducted that extend the ideas in this work. I give some ideas here: We could extend the loop classification to other dimensions. More specifically, in 3d it might be possible that the boundary state of a 181 182 CONCLUSION cyclic process is a state with non-trivial invertible topological order. It could also be interesting to extend the loop classification to states that have non-trivial anyonic topological order. In this case as well, there are loops that might be non-trivial even without the application of any symmetry. In fact in [1] it has been shown there are locally generated loops of the toric code ground-state that exchange the e and m excitations. Such situations could really benefit from a rigorous treatise. There is another interesting generalisation of the loop classification coming from Kitaevs spectrum hypothesis (see e.g. [64]). The generalisation is that in stead of comparing the loops of d + 1 dimensional SPTs with their d-dimensional boundary states, we compare maps from the suspension of some differential manifold M to d + 1-dimensional SPTs to maps from M to the d-dimensional SPTs. This is related to the higher Berry curvature index you will find in [32] and [3]. In conclusion, multiple directions hold the promise of revealing or analysing fascinating new phenomena that could enrich our understanding of quantum matter. Appendix A App endix to chapter 4 A.1 Appendix: basic tricks in Hilbert space In this appendix we collect a few lemmas dealing with zero-dimensional systems, i.e. we deal with Hilbert spaces without any local structure. A.1.1 An estimate for bipartite systems Lemma A.1.1. Consider a bipartite system H = Ha Hb. Let P = Pa Pb where Pa, Pb are rank-one projectors acting on Hilbert spaces Ha, Hb. Let be a density matrix on H and let a, b be the reduced density matrices on Ha, Hb. Then || P ||1 6||a Pa||1 + 6||b Pb||1 Proof. We abuse notation by writing Pi to denote Pi 1. First, || PiPi||1 ||PiPi||1 + ||PiPi||1 + ||PiPi||1 ||Pi||2||Pi||2 + ||Pi||2||Pi||2 + Tr(Pi) 3 Tr(Pi) 3||i Pi||1 The second inequality follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the last one is because Tr(Pi) = Tr(Pi(i Pi)) ||i Pi||1, 183 APPENDIX TO CHAPTER ?? where we used that Pi is rank one. Then, we bound ||PbPb PbPaPaPb||1 || PaPa||1 and so || PbPaPaPb||1 || PiPi||1 := 3 ||i Pi||1. i=a,b i=a,b Since P = PaPb is rank one, we conclude that |1 Tr(P )| = | Tr( Tr(P )P )| || Tr(P )P ||1 = || P P ||1 . Hence || P ||1 || Tr(P )P ||1 + ||(1 Tr(P ))P ||1 2. A.1.2 Parallel transport We now turn to the Proof of Lemma 4.6.5. Let the normalized vectors , H be representativesFirstly, we note that || || = 1 a2. We write then = a + 1 a2 of , . They can be chosen such that a := , is real, with 0 a 1. where is orthogonal to and has unit norm. Let now(s) := y(s) + 1 y(s)2, y = a + (1 a)(1 (1 s)2) Then, i. ||(s)|| = 1, ii. (0) = and (1) = , iii. |sy|, |s1 y(s)2| 2 1 a. Let P (s) denote the orthogonal rank-one projector onto the span of (s). We consider the adiabatic generator K (s) = i(P (s)P (s) P (s)P (s)), (A.1.1) which satisfies P(s) = i[K(s),P(s)]. We then have ||K(s)|| 2||P(s)|| 4||(s)|| 81 a 8|| ||. This proves items (i,ii). We turn to item (iii). If h/ = 0, then U(g) = z(g) and so U(g)(s) = z(g)(s) for all s. It follows that P(s),P(s) are invariantand U(g) = z(g) with z(g) = z(g) =: z(g). Therefore U(g) = z(g) and so is K(s) by definition (A.1.1). APPENDIX: BASIC TRICKS IN HILBERT SPACE 185 A.1.3 Contracting loops In this section, we prove Lemma 4.7.9 on the contractibility of loops in Hilbert space. Throughout this work, we often need to appeal to the fundamental theorem of calculus for Banach-space valued functions defined on the interval [0, 1]. Let X be an arbitrary Banach space. We first recall that a strongly measurable Banach- space valued function J : [0, 1] X : s J (s) is Bochner integrable if and only if 0s du||J (u)|| < , see [23]. We consider functions F : [0, 1] X : s F (s) that satisfy the following property: s F (s) F (0) = duJ (u), 0 sup ||J (s)|| < s[0,1] where s J(s) strongly measurable. In particular the function s H(s)[A], for a TDI H and A Aal satisfies this property, with J = H(u){[H(u),A]}. For the application we have in mind here, it suffices to restrict our attention to the case of finite-dimensional Banach spaces. In that case (more generally in any Banach space with the Radon-Nikodym property with respect to the Lebesgue measure), a function s F(s) satisfies the property above if and only if it is Lipschitz continuous, in which case J(s) is its derivative almost everywhere. We say that CF is a Lipschitz bound if sups[0,1]||J(s)|| CF. We now come to the Proof of Lemma 4.7.9. As remarked in (4.5.17), the evolved state (s) = E(s) is of the form (s)=(0)Ad(U(s)), U(s)=1+i duE(u)U(u). s 0 We choose a unit vector representative of (0), and we set (s) = U(s). Then s (s) is Lipschitz, and its almost sure derivative is iE(s)(s). Of course, changing the phase of (s) does not affect the state (s) and we use this to introduce a crucial modification of s (s). Lemma A.1.2. There exists a Lipschitz function a : [0,1] U(1), with Lipschitz bound 4|||E|||, and such that (s) = a(s)(s) satisfies k(s) := Re(s), 1/2. Proof. Let k(s) = Re(s), . As s (s) is Lipschitz continuous with bound |||E|||, so is k(s). Then the sets 0 = {s [0, 1], k(s) > 0}, 1 = {s [0, 1], k(s) < 1/2} are open and dist(0,1) 2|||E|||. 1 We can therefore construct a continuous, U(1)-valued function a with Lipschitz bound 4|||E||| such that a(0) = 1, a(1) = 1, and the vector a(s)(s) satisfies the required properties. We started from a loop () and we now have a function s (s). The latter function is not necessarily a loop of unit vectors in the Hilbert space, but it is a family of representatives of (s), in particular (0) = , (1) . (A.1.2) We now set for [0, 1], (s) := N (s, ) 1 ( + (1 )(s)), N (s, ) = 2+(1)2+2(1)k(s). With this definition and from the above construction of (s) and (A.1.2), it follows that i. N 1/4, ii. ||(s)|| = 1, iii. (0) = and (1) , iv. 0(s) = (s) and 1(s) = . Since k(s) is Lipschitz, and N 1/4, we infer that 1 is Lipschitz. Therefore, and since s a(s) and are Lipschitz, also s (s) is Lipschitz. A short N calculation yields ||s(s)|| 20|||E|||. We denote by P = P (, s) the rank-one projector on the range of (s). Writing P = ||, the Lipschitz continuity APPENDIX: LOCALITY ESTIMATES of s (s) gives that s P (, s) is Lipschitz with ||sP (, s)|| 40|||E|||. We can now set E(s) = i[sP (, s), P (, s)] to satisfy item iii) of the lemma. Moreover, |||E||| 80|||E|||. To construct the family Fs(), we proceed analogously, but the considerations are simpler because the functions (s) are clearly Lipschitz in . Here we find ||(s)|| 52 and so |||Fs||| 208. A.2 Appendix: Locality estimates We review the standard propagation bounds that are necessary for the proofs of Lemma 4.5.2. These bounds go back to [38] but we use proofs in [44]. A.2.1 Functions N+ R+ Just as in the main text, we denote N+ = {1, 2, . . .} and we consistently denote by r variables in N+. We define transformations M, S, P on bounded functions N + R+; M(f)(r)=maxrrf(r) P(f)(r)=rf(r) S(f)(r)=supN+ sup i f(ri) (r1,...,r)(N+): ri=r iThe definition of S(f ) is taken from [15] and its use lies in the fact that f = S(f ), for f < 1, is logarithmically superadditive, i.e, f(r1)f(r2) f(r1 + r2) r1, r2 N+. (A.2.1) We now consider the following transformations: i. f f = M(pf ) for some polynomial p with positive coefficients; ii. f f = M ( rb ) orthberwNis+e , for some a N+, b N. { f 0 a aiii. f f = S(f ) for f < 1. These transformations have the following important property, referring to the class F introduced in 4.2.2. Lemma A.2.1. If f F , then f is affiliated to f and depends on the parameters a, b, p, in the sense of Definition 4.5.1. Proof. Only item iii) needs a proof. Note first that if f F with F logarithmically superadditive, then S(f ) S(F ) = F . Assume that f (r) Cecr for some 0 < 1. By tuning c, we can choose C = 1, so that f is bounded above by a logarithmically superadditive function r ecr. The claim now follows. Finally, we will often use without comment that max(f1, f2) F if f1, f2 F. Local decompositions We recall the canonical decomposition of observables A A into finitely suppported terms centered at some j Z, A = kN Aj,k, introduced in Section 4.5.3. We will use the bound ||Ax,k|| {||A Bkc(j)[A]|| + ||A Bck1 (j)[A]|| k > 0 ||A|| k = 0 (A.2.2) and the terms on the right-hand side will in practice be bounded by the following standard result: Lemma A.2.2. For any A A, ||A Zc[A]|| sup ||[O, A]||. OAZc ,||O||=1 Proof. If A is a local observable supported in a finite set X, then the claim follows from the expression Zc[A] = dX\Z(U)UAU with X\Z the Haar measure on the unitary group in AX\Z. The general case follows by approximating A with a sequence of local elements. A.2.2 Lieb-Robinson bounds in finite volume In the present section, we restrict our setup to finite volume, as it is mostly done for the discussion of Lieb-Robinson bounds. More concretely, we assume that all the operators appearing below, in particular the spatial terms of the APPENDIX: LOCALITY ESTIMATES interactions, belong to the algebra A[L,L] for a large but finite L. In order to ensure a smooth passing to infinite volume in Section A.2.3, we will only consider interactions and TDIs that are restrictions of infinite volume interactions and TDIs. For example, a TDI H(L) on A[L,L] will be the restriction of a TDI H on the full chain algebra as defined in Section 4.2.2, namely HS(L) = HS whenever S is a subset of [L, L]. The advantage of this is that the decay function fH associated with H can be chosen fixed and independent of L. Similarly, all estimates are understood to be independent of L. In order not to overburden the notation, we will not keep the superscripts L below. Let H be a TDI as introduced above and let H be the associated almost local evolution, in the sense that H (s)[A] = A + i du H (u){[H (u), A]}. s 0 In contrast with the main text, we allow here arbitrary times s R. The existence and uniqueness of this finite-volume dynamics follows from elementary facts on matrix-valued ODEs. We now state a version of the Lieb-Robinson bound, using the language introduced in section A.2.1. Lemma A.2.3. Let h = S(max( Mv(PfFfF) , Mv(PfHfH) )), v(f ) = sup(Pf (r)) r f(r) = M{(r1)2Ph(r1) r1 + 0 2 2 2 N otherwise Then for any subset X , ||H (s)(F )||X,f 8esv(fH )CH v(fF )||F ||X,fF where CH = supsR ||H (s)||fH . This bound follows from equations (3.41-3.42) of [44] once one proves that the reminder term RN (t) appearing in (3.41) in [44] vanishes as N . The vanishing of this remainder term is proven analogously to the bounds that we derive below and so we do not comment on this further. A.2.3 Passage to infinite volume As was already pointed out in the original [38], the finite volume Lieb-Robinson bound implies the convergence of the -automorphisms H(L) as L . Lemma A.2.4. Let H(L) be the finite volume almost local evolution above. Then, for any A A and s R, the limit H(s)[A] = LlimH(L)(s)[A] exists and defines astrongly continuous family of -automorphisms solving the Heisenberg equation (4.2.1). The extension of H (s) to interactions, as defined in Section 4.5.3, satisfies the same bound as given in Lemma A.2.3. The proof of this claim relies on Lemma A.2.3, its proof and most importantly of the fact that the bounds therein hold uniformly in L. Since the argument is well-known, we omit it here. Finally, we can now prove the bound of Lemma 4.5.2 item (iv). It follows because we can now restrict to s [0, 1], and hence the prefactor 8esv(fH)CH v(fF ) can be omitted by choosing f judiciously. A.2.4 Useful local transformations We say that a function f F is weakly affiliated to f F if f(r) Cecr for some 1 implies that for any 0 < < , there are c,C such that f(r) Cecr, cf. Definition 4.5.1. For any function w L1(R) that satisfies the decay property |w(t)| Cec(log|t||t|)2 , (A.2.11) we define the map KwH : Aal Aal KwH [A] = w(t)H (t)[A]dt and this map is extended to a map on interactions, just as we did for automorphisms. Lemma A.2.5. For an interaction H and f F such that ||H||f < CH, ||KwH[A]||X,f ||A||X,f, A Aal, for some f that is weakly affiliated to f and that depends on CH. Given a pair of interactions H1,H2 such that ||Hj||f < CH, we have ||KwH2[A] KHw1[A]||X,f C||A||X,f||H2 H1||f As we shall see shortly, the function f depends on w, in particular on the decay rate appearing in (A.2.11). The map Kw[] will be used in Lemma A.3.2 with two different functions having the same rate c. While this rate is directly related to a spectral gap, we will show that this gap is larger than 1 in our construction, see Proposition A.3.1; in particular, this constant depends on no parameter 2 of our setting. We therefore chose not to emphasize the w-dependence in the lemma. APPLICATIONS OF SPECTRAL FLOW Proof. Let X be such that ||A||X,f < and let x X. Let h be the function appearing in Lemma A.2.3, and let tr(O) = ||O trBr1(x)c O||. We estimate tr(KHw[A]) |w(t)|tr(H(t)[A])dt (A.2.12) |w(t)| min h(r)2e|t|v(f )CH v(f )||A||X,f , 2||A|| dt ( ) (A.2.13) ( ( ) 2||A||X,f h(r)||w||L1 + |t| logv((fv()fC)Hh(r)) )|w(t)|f (1)dt (A.2.14) since ||A|| ||A||X,f f (1). To estimate the integral in the last line, we observe that |w(t)|(|t| > a)dt Caeclog(a)2 . a Therefore, we get the bound tr(KwH[A]) 2||A||X,f||w||L1 h(r) + Ca(r)eclog(aa((rr)))2 ( ) , a(r) = v(f)CH log(v(f)h(r)) . The second term in the bracket, considered as a function of r, is in F. Therefore, we have tr(KwH[A]) ||A||j,f(r) for some F that depends on h,f. In fact, it is weakly affiliated to h and therefore to f. The remainder of the proof follows the end of the proof of Lemma A.2.3. The second part of the lemma follows similarly using Duhamels formula. A.3 Applications of spectral flow The aim of this section is to review the proofs of the stability result Proposition 4.8.3 and the uniqueness result Proposition 4.8.2. As already mentioned, Proposition 4.8.3 is a standard result, but the present setting allows for some simplifications. In contrast, Proposition 4.8.2 seems not be contained in the literature. A.3.1 Spectral flow for gapped systems We start out in the same finite-volume setting as in Section A.2.2. The finite volume C-algebra is isomorphic to a simple matrix algebra that we write as M acting on a finite-dimensional Hilbert space. The trace on M is written as Tr(). Throughout this section, we fix a constant CH and a function f and consider interactions such that ||H||f < CH. Let us write () for the spectrum of an operator. Definition A.3.1. We say that H has a spectral gap if E0 = min(H) is a simple eigenvalue of H and 0 < dist(E0, (H) \ E0) In accordance with our finite volume conventions, the independence of on the finite size of the system is part of the definition. In what follows, we always use P to denote the one-dimensional spectral projector corresponding to E0 and we write P = 1 P . We write P to denote the state on M given by P (A) = Tr(P A), A M. Lemma A.3.2. Let H have a spectral gap . There are integrable functions v, q satisfying the bound (A.2.11) such that i. v(t)dt = 1 and v 0; ii. KHv (H ) = H ; iii. [KHv (A), P ] = 0 for any A M; iv. [H, KHq (A)] = A for any A M such that A = P AP + P AP . Proof. We denote by the Fourier transform of an integrable function w. We choose a non-negative v such that v is compactly supported in (, ) and v(0) = 1. We choose q and such that q(x) = 21x for |x| . The possibility of doing this while satisfying the bound (A.2.11) was explained in [8]. Item (ii) is immediate and properties (iii,iv) follow by spectral calculus. The following lemma shows an important application of the above construction. This idea of the lemma goes back to [28], see also [8]. Lemma A.3.3. Let H be a TDI such that |||H(s)|||f < CH and H(s) has a spectral gap for all s [0,1]. Let P(s) denote the ground state projector for H(s). If s H (s) = H (0) + duY (u), |||Y |||f < , (A.3.1) 0 then there exists a TDI such that P (s) = P (0) (s) and such that ||| |||f C|||Y |||f for some f weakly affiliated to f and that depends on CH. Proof. We define the TDI by (s) = iKqH(s)[Y (s)]. The required bound on holds by Lemma A.2.5. By (A.3.1), s H(s) is Lipschitz with bounded derivative Y (s) almost everywhere. By the gap assumption, s P (s), and therefore s P (s)[A] (for any A M), have the same property and one checks using Lemma A.3.2 that the derivative of the latter equals P (s)([ (s), A]) almost everywhere. We conclude that P (s) = P (0) (s), as required. A.3.2 Stability of the gap For the next result, we recall the definition of the interaction F given at the beginning of Section 4.8, but now restricted to a finite volume. Recall in particular (i) that F has only on-site terms with ||Fj|| = 1 and (ii) that F has a spectral gap equal to 1. It follows that ||F||f = f(1) for all f F. The next proposition is a special case of the celebrated stability result of [14]. Proposition A.3.1. For any f F , there is (f ) > 0 such that, for any interaction W with ||W ||f (f ), the interaction H = F + W has a spectral gap = 1 . 2 Proof of Proposition A.3.1 We adopt the notation of Lemmas A.3.2 and A.3.3. Let H(s) = F + sW with s [0, 1]. We let s0 be the maximal value in [0, 1] such that the spectral gap of H is at least 1/2 for s [0, s0]. Note that the spectral gap of F is equal to 1 and that s0 > 0 by spectral perturbation theory for finite dimensional matrices (here, no uniformity of s0 in the finite volume is claimed nor required!) If s0 < 1, then necessarily the spectral gap of H(s0) is equal to 1/2. We prove now that this gap is actually not smaller than 1 (f ), thus forcing a contradiction if (f ) < 1/2. Let be the TDI of Lemma A.3.3 generating the spectral flow automorphism which exists by of the gap assumption, and let H := (s0)[H(s0)]. Note that H, being isospectral to H, has a simple eigenvalue at the bottom of its spectrum. By the spectral flow, P := P(0) is its ground state projector. Since H(s0) is an interaction and the spectral flow is an almost local evolution, we can write H = j Hj such that Hj is anchored at j and such that ||Hj||j,f C for some f weakly affiliated to f. Next, we use the diagonalization operator F = KvH, see Lemma A.3.2, so that H F (H ) = F (Hj ) = j is written as a sum of almost-local terms F(Hj) anchored at sites j that satisfy [P,F(Hj)] = 0. Let now Aj := (F (Hj ) Fj ) P (F (Hj ) Fj ). The operators Aj and the sum A = Aj j have the following properties: i. F + Ahas the same spectral gap as H , hence as H . ii. The terms Aj satisfy Aj P = P Aj = 0. iii. There is f F weakly affiliated to f such that sup ||Aj ||j,f C ||W ||f j where we denoted || ||j,f = || ||{j },f . (A.3.2) (A.3.3) (A.3.4) The first two properties are by construction and by the fact that P is one- dimensional. In order to derive the third one, we note that KFv [Fj ] = Fj because F is a sum of on-site terms and write F (Hj ) Fj = KHv [Hj ] KFv [Fj ] = KHv [Hj Fj ] + (KHv [Fj ] KFv [Fj ]) The bound (A.3.4) follows from ||Hj Fj ||j,f C ||W ||f and Lemma A.2.5. By the locality property (A.3.4), we know that Aj can be written as a sum terms anchored in j, with increasing support and rapidly decreasing norm. We need to modify this decomposition so that each of the terms, and not just the sum, satisfies the above item ii). Lemma A.3.4. For each j, we can write Aj = r Dj,r such that the following holds (we suppress the index j and we write Br for the ball with radius r centred at j): i. DrPBr = PBrDr = 0; ii. ||Dr|| f(r)||Aj||j,f, where f is the function appearing in (A.3.4) and fis affiliated to f. Note that fis therefore weakly affiliated to f. Proof. We define the conditional expectation Er(O) = TrBrc(OPBrc) 1Brc Since the volume is finite, Brc = and hence TrBcr(O) = O for large enough r. We set Dr = EE1r((AAjj)), Er1(Aj), r => 1 { r 1 Because of finite volume, we have Dr = 0 for large enough r, and Aj = r Dr as required. Further, the product property P = PBr PBcr implies that P Er (Aj ) = Er (Aj )P = TrBrc (Aj P ) PBrc = 0 because of Aj P = 0, and then also PBr Er (A) = Er (A)PBr = 0 for r r. This implies (i). In order to get estimate (ii), we use the standard decomposition Aj = k0 Aj,k described in Section 4.5.3 and recall that ||Aj,k || f(k + 1)||Aj||j,f where f is affiliated to f, see Lemma 4.5.5, item i. The bound ||Dr|| 2 kr ||Aj,k|| then yields the claim with f(r) = 2 kr f(k + 1). From DrPBr = PBrDr = 0 and FBr 1 PBr, we conclude that Dr ||Dr||FBr (A.3.5) where the inequality is here in the sense of operators. We now lift this inequality to A. Lemma A.3.5. The following operator bound holds: A C(f)||W||fF, where C(f) depends only on f F, in particular not onL. Proof. To get the statement of the lemma, we first write F = Fj = r2 Fj = ar2 Nr (j ) FBr (j ) 1 1 1 j a r j r j where a = 12 = 2 and Nr (j ) is the number of balls of radius r that contain j ; in prar1tircular Nr (j ) 2r + 1. Then, reinstating the site index j in 6 Aj and using (A.3.5), we get A = Dj,r ||Dj,r||FBr(j) 1 j r r j r j ar2Nr(j)FBr(j) = F with = supr,j ||Dj,r||ar2Nr(j). To estimate , we use Lemma A.3.4 item ii and recall (A.3.4) to conclude that Ca||W ||f sup(r2(2r + 1)f(r)) r which is finite since f F . It only depends on f since f does. This yields the claim of the lemma. From standard spectral perturbation theory, it then follows that that the spectral gap of F + A, and therefore of H, is not smaller than 1 C(f)||W||f, which is in contradiction to the assumption that s0 < 1. A.3.3 Passage to infinite volume: Proof of Proposition 4.8.3 The previous sections of this appendix were staged in finite volume, but now we revert back to infinite volume. Interactions in particular again refer to infinite-volume objects, and we derive finite-volume interactions from them by setting HS(L) = (S [L,L])HS Note that bounds are inherited from infinite volume, i.e. ||H(L)||f ||H||f. For convenience, we restate Proposition 4.8.3. Proposition 4.8.3. For any h F, there is 0< 3(h) < 1 such that, for any pair of TDIs W and Y satisfying |||W |||h 3(h), |||Y |||h < , W (z) W (0) = dzY (z), (4.8.3) z 0 the following holds: There exists a TDI satisfying ||| |||h |||Y |||h for h F depending only on h, such that, if the pure state is a ground state of F + W (0), then (z) = (0) (z), z [0, 1] (4.8.4) is a ground state of the interaction F + W (z). If Y is G-invariant, then also can be chosen G-invariant. Proof. We note that H(L) = F (L) + W (L) satisfies all conditions of Proposition A.3.1 if we take 1(h) small enough. Therefore, they also satisfy all conditions of Lemma A.3.3, with the TDI Y in that lemma given by Y (L) (derived from the infinite volume TDI Y ). We denote by PL(s) the spectral projections of Lemma A.3.3 by and (L) the TDIs constructed in Lemma A.3.3. The notation reflects the fact that the latter are not restrictions of an infinite volume interaction. However, the L-dependent TDIs (L) satisfy the following compatibility requirement: As a consequence of the Lieb-Robinson bound, the limits S (s) := lim (L, s)S (A.3.6) L exist, uniformly in s. It follows that the TDI inherits the bounds of Lemma A.3.3 on (L) and we conclude that ||| |||h |||Y |||h with h F depending only on h. To complete the proof of Proposition 4.8.3, we still need to show that (s) = (0) (s) is a ground state associated to H(s). Here (0) is the product state that is a ground state associated to the interaction F . By (A.3.6) and the Lieb-Robinson bound, we see that (s)[A] = lim PL(s)[A] L for A A with local support. Since PL(s) are ground states associated to the truncated interactions H(L), we deduce by density that (s) is a ground state associated to the interaction H(s). A.3.4 Proof of Proposition 4.8.2 Our aim in this final section is to prove the uniqueness of the ground state (in the sense of Defintion 4.8.2) of the interaction F + W (s) for W small enough. The following lemma is a special case of what was already proven at the end of Section A.3.3. Recall that PL is the state on AL corresponding to the projector PL, i.e. PL(A) = TrL(PLA). Then Lemma A.3.6. For A A with finite support, the limit (A) = limPL(A) L exists. By density, extends to a state on A. For any ground state associated to H, the invariance property (4.8.2) implies that (A) = (KHv(A)) = lim(KvH(L)(A)) L with the function v as in Lemma A.3.2 item iii). The second equality is by the Lieb-Robinson bound. Now KvH(L)(PLAPL) = KHv(L)(PLAPL) = 0, where PL = 1 PL. Hence, (A) = lim((KHv(L)(PLAPL)) + (KHv(L)(PLAPL)) (A.3.7) L = lim((PLAPL) + (KHv(L)(PLAPL)) (A.3.8) Lwhere the second equality follows because PL is a one-dimensional spectral projection of H(L). If we choose A with finite support, then for large enough L, (PLAPL) = (PL) TrL(PLA). Since (PL) [0, 1], there is a subsequence Ln such that the limit limn (PLn ) exists. We call this limit a [0, 1]. We then see from Lemma A.3.6 that lim(PLnAPLn) = a(A) n and this equality extends by density to any A A. From (A.3.8), it then follows that (A) = a(A) + (1 a)(A) (A.3.9) where, in case a < 1, (A) = lim (PLn)(PLnKvH(Ln)(A)PLn) 1 n and we used Lemma A.3.2 item iii) to commute the projectors. The existence of the limit follows because the first term in (A.3.8) has a limit. We now claim that is a state. Indeed, positivity follows from the nonnegativity of the function v. Normalization follows from KHv(Ln)(I) = I since v = 1. Now, since is assumed to be pure, (A.3.9) means that either a = 0 or a = 1, since we can easily check that and are not equal. We will exclude the case a = 0, which will end the proof. We define the boundary operator BL = WS S:S[L,L]0,S[L,L]c satisfying ||BL|| 2f(1)||W||f. By the variational principle Lemma 4.8.3 (H(L) + BL) (PL |[L,L]c)(H(L) + BL) which implies (H(L)) PL(H(L)) + 2||BL|| By the gap assumption, we have also (H(L)) (PL)E0,L + (1 (PL))(E0,L + ) and hence (PL)E0,L + (1 (PL))(E0,L + ) E0,L + 2||BL|| from which we conclude that (1(PL)) 2||BL|| 4f(1)||W||f. If ||W||f is small enough, we get that a = liminfL(PL) > 0 and so the alternative a = 0 is indeed excluded. Appendix B Appendix to chapter 5 B.1 Representations and states In this section we summarize all the results we need from [11]. Theorem B.1.1. Let be a state on a C -algebra A. It follows that there exists a cyclic representation (H , , ) of A such that (A) = , (A) for all A A. Moreover, the representation is unique up to unitary equivalence. Proof. Theorem 2.3.16 in [11]. We will call this cyclic representation a GNS triple for . Corollary B.1.2. Let be a state over the C -algebra A and a *- automorphism of A which leaves invariant, i.e., = . Let (H , , ) be a GNS triple for . It follows that there exists a uniquely determined unitary operator U , such that U (A)U = (A) for all A A, and U = . 203 If furthermore, is pure then (up to a phase) there even exists a unique U without requiring the second condition. Proof. The proof of this corollary is a combination of Corollary 2.3.17 and Theorem 2.3.19 from [11]. The following lemma does not come from Bratteli-Robinson but in stead follows from Wigners theorem: Lemma B.1.3. Let A and B be arbitrary unital C-algebras. Let (HA, A) and (HB, B) be arbitrary irreducible -representations on A and B respectively. Let U U(HA HB) be such that there exists an A Aut(A) and an B Aut(B) satisfying Ad(U) (A B) = A A B B then there exists aUA U(HA) and a UB U(HB) such that U = UA UB. Proof. From the assumptions we see that A A Ad(U) A B(A 1) = A A(A) 1 B(HA) 1. (B.1.1) (B.1.2) (B.1.3) Since Ad(U) is continuous in weak operator topology (on B(HA HB)), it follows that we can extend the map Ad(U)|Im(A) : Im(A) 1 B(HA) 1 (B.1.4) to the closure in weak operator topology. By irreducibility (and Von Neumanns bicomutant theorem), we get that A(A) = B(HA) and therefore we get a map Ad(U)|B(HA)1 : B(HA) 1 B(HA) 1. (B.1.5) By restriction this gives rise to an automorphism A : U(HA) U(HA). By Wigners theorem any automorphism of B(HA) is inner and therefore there exists a UA such that A = Ad(UA). Doing the same on B gives us similarly a B and a UB. We now get Ad(U ) (A B ) = A A B B = Ad(UA UB ) (A B ). (B.1.6) By the irreducibility of A B we get that (up to some irrelevant phase) we need that U = UA UB concluding the proof. We will now show that the expression in equation (B.4.60) is the identity. First we will show that the As in equation (B.4.60) cancel. By equation (B.4.61) we get that Ad(vyvvy) 0 0 0H;1 1H;0split(A) = 0 0 0H;1 1H;0split (A). (B.4.67) Filling this in shows that the As cancel. Now, what is left to show is that vyvvyv = 1 (B.4.68) which is equivalent to showing that Ad(y)(vv) = vv. (B.4.69) To show this, first we use the definitions of these objects to see that this is equivalent to showing that (1(a)a) = 1(a)a. (B.4.70) However, since Ad(1(a)a) = 1 0H;1split 1H;0 0H;1 1H;0split 1 = 1 1, (B.4.71) we get that 1(a)a U(AW(C)) = U(AW(C)c), where the last equality is again because of section 3 in [43]. This concludes the proof of B.4.70 concluding the proof of this lemma. B.5 Some properties of 1 and 2 We now prove lemma 5.5.23. Lemma B.5.1. The 1 and 2 defined previously satisfy that for any x IAC(0, , ) we have that 1(Ad(wpWgwp)(x)) = Ad(2(wpWgwp))(1(x)) (B.5.1) 1(Ad(vs)(x)) = Ad(vs)(1(x)) (B.5.2) 2(Ad(vs)(wpWgwp)) = Ad(vs)(2(wpWgwp)) (B.5.3) for any p, s {0, 1}. For the second equation we need the stronger condition that x IACW (0, , ). Proof. The proof of this lemma is analogous to the proof of lemma B.4.3. The only difference is that now the Wg is generalized to wpWgwp. This is possible because the support of g is smaller in assumption 5.3.5 then it is in assumption 5.3.2 and therefore everything still splits and therefore, everything is still well defined. B.6 Proof of lemma 5.3.13 In this section we prove lemma 5.3.13: Proof. We will only prove the first item as all the other proofs are analogous. First notice that the equivalence implies that there exist product states 1 P(1) and 2 P(2) and group actions 1 and 2 such that the combinations (1, 1) and (2, 2) are trivial (see 5.2.2 for what this means). Moreover these will satisfy that there exists a unitary transformation of the on site Hilbert space, V such that 1 stack 1 iV = 2 stack 2 0;1 V U1(g) 1(g)V = U2(g) 2(g) (B.6.1) for some G-invariant locally generated automorphism. Using item 1 and item 3 of 5.3.14 this implies that IndexAno1trsatnacsk1,U11(1 stack1) = IndexAno2trsatnacsk2,U22(2stack2). (B.6.2) Using item 2 of 5.3.14 this is satisfied if Indexno1,tra1ns(1) = Indexno2,tra2ns(2) = 1. (B.6.3) This is trivially true. Only in the last part with the H1-valued index does one need that the (,) pairs are trivial (see remark 5.5.11). For the other three statements it is enough that we have G-invariant product states. (B.7.55) TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN ONE DIMENSION If we now insert vv, we obtain 2(g) = vwgRwbRg,1vv(gR)vhgvgRvKgR,1(bR1,g)w(KgR,1)v(gR)vw (B.7.56) where the cancelation is due to the fact that vgRv IACR(0, , ) whereas hg IACL(0, , ). (B.7.57) (B.7.58) (B.7.59) B.8 Translation invariance in one dimension Let B be the quasi local C algebra defined with on the one dimensional lattice. Let Ui hom(G,U(Ai)) (for i Z) be the on site group action. Let g bewill look at states satisfying the split property. We say that P(B) satisfiesagain so that for each finite I Z, gI = Ad(iI Ui(g)). In this section, wethe split property iff. it is quasi equivalent to |L |R. This implies that there exists a GNS triple of that is of the form (H = HL HR, = L R, ). (B.8.1) We will denote the space of pure states satisfying the split property by SP(A). Now let us additionally ask that is invariant under the group action (g = ). The following now holds: Lemma B.8.1. There exist maps u : G U(H) (for all {L,R}) satisfying Ad(u(g)) = g uL(g) uR(g) = . (B.8.2) They are unique up to a G-dependent phase. Proof. See [47]. This can now be used to define the one dimensional SPT index: Lemma B.8.2. There exists a 2-cochain C : G2 U (1) that satisfies uR(g)uR(h)uR(gh) = C(g,h)1HR uL(g)uL(h)uL(gh) = C(g,h)11HL. (B.8.3) Its second group cohomology class is independent of the choice of GNS triple or the choice of (a G-dependent) phase in uR(g). This index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms generated by G-invariant interactions. Proof. Again see [47]. Now let us assume additionally (on top of the split property and the G-invariance) that be translation invariant. To this end, let be the automorphism that translates B by one site to the right. We assume that = . The following now holds: Lemma B.8.3. There exists a unique w U (H) such that Ad(w) = w = . (B.8.4) Proof. Since = , we get that (H, , ) (H, , ). (B.8.5) u.e. The uniqueness of the GNS triple now implies the existence of this w. Its uniqueness follows from the irreducibility of . We can use this to define an additional 1d index for translation invariant states. To do this, we will need to use the finiteness of the group explicitly. We will use one particular property of this, namely that finite groups have discrete U(1) representations. By this we mean the following: Lemma B.8.4. Let G be a finite group. There exists an > 0 such that for all hom(G, U (1)), min |(g) 1| < (B.8.6) gG\1 holds if and only if = 1. Proof. We can simply take := |exp(2i/|G|) 1| (B.8.7) TRANSLATION INVARIANCE IN ONE DIMENSION where |G| is the amount of group elements. This is because if we assume that this minimum is smaller then for some hom(G, U (1)), we can reach a contradiction. Namely, let g G be the group element that gives the minimum. For all n [1, |G| + 1], we get that all of the (g)n need to be different. This implies that multiplying g, n times needs to be different for each n but N this is impossible since there are only |G| group elements. Lemma B.8.5. There exists a (unique) hom(G, U (1)) satisfying that (U1(g))(1HL uR(g)) = (g)w(1HL uR(g))w. (B.8.8) This index is invariant under locally generated automorphisms generated by one parameter families of interactions in BF([0,1]) (with F as presented in (5.2.17)) that are both G and translation invariant. Proof. The fact that exists follows from the fact that is irreducible and combined with the fact that Ad((U1(g))(1HL uR(g))) = Ad(w(1HL uR(g))w) = g[1,[. (B.8.9) The fact that is a U(1)representation follows from the fact that uR is the lift of a projective representation. Suppose that uR(g)uR(h) = C(g,h)uR(gh) then (U1(g))(1HL uR(g))(U1(h))(1HL uR(h)) = C(g, h)(U1(gh))(1HL uR(gh)) (B.8.10) on the one hand whereas w(1HL uR(g))ww(1HL uR(h))w = C(g, h)w(1HL uR(gh))w. (B.8.11) These two equations can only be consistent if (g)(h) = (gh). The proof that this is independent of the choice of GNS triple is straightforward. Now we need to show that this index is invariant under LGAs generated by G-invariant interactions. To this end let F be our F-function from equation (5.2.17). Let BF([0, 1]) be a G-invariant, translation invariant interaction. For simplicity of notation let split = 1(L) + (R). Let [0, 1] A U(A) be a norm continuous one parameter family such that 0; = Ad(A) 0;split A0 = 1A. (B.8.12) and define A := A1. This exists because of lemma B.9.1. By construction (H, 0;s1plit, (A)) is a GNS triple of 0;1. Let w := (A)w(A) then (g) := (U1(g))uR(g)wuR(g)w (B.8.13) is the index of 0;1. Working this out gives (g) = (U1(g))uR(g)(A)w(A)uR(g)(A)w(A) (B.8.14) = (U1(g))uR(g)w((A)A)uR(g)(A(A))w (B.8.15) = (U1(g))uR(g)wuR(g) gR((A)A)(A(A))w (B.8.16) = (g)w gR((A)A)(A(A))w. (B.8.17) This shows that we conclude the proof if we can show that gR((A)A) = (A)A. (B.8.18) We will do this proof in two steps. The first step is that we prove that Ad(gR((A)A)) = Ad((A)A). (B.8.19) We use the first equation of (B.8.12) and obtain Ad(gR((A)A)) = gR Ad((A)A) (gR)1 (B.8.20) = gR 0;s1plit 1;0 1 0;1 1;s0plit (gR)1 (B.8.21) = gR 0;(1split) 1;s0plit (gR)1 (B.8.22) = Ad((A)A). (B.8.23) This shows that there exists some hom(G, U (1)) such that (g) = gR((A)A)(A(A)). (B.8.24) However since this has to hold for each [0, 1] we can define for each some hom(G, U (1)) through (g) = gR((A)A)(A(A)). (B.8.25) This implies that (g) = 1(g) has to be connected to 0(g) = 1. Now we will use that the U(1) representations of a finite group are discrete. More specifically we will use lemma B.8.4. This implies that (g) = 1 for all g G in our case (as we can just use lemma B.8.4 as many times as needed and obtain that (g) is constant for all g G). All together we constructed a proof of the following theorem: PROPERTIES OF LOCALLY GENERATED AUTOMORPHISMS: 1D Theorem B.8.6. There exist maps Index1d : { S P (A)| g = } H 2(G, T) (B.8.26) Index1d trans : { SP(A)| g = and = } H1(G, T) = hom(G, T). (B.8.27) For any Ginvariant family of interactions BF ([0, 1]), we have that Index1d() = Index1d( 0;1). For any Ginvariant family of interactions BF ([0, 1]) that is also translation invariant, we have that Index1d trans() = Index1d trans( 0;1). There exist maps AL : [0,1] U(AL) : AL() AR : [0,1] U(AR) : AR() (B.10.38) both continuous in norm topology and : [0,1] Aut(AW(C)c) : () (B.10.39) where {U, D} and {L, (R)}, all four continuous in strong5 topology, satisfying that 0H;split 1 H;s0plit = 0H;L 0H;(R) H;s0plit (B.10.40) = Ad(AL()) Ad(AR()) () {U,D}, {L,(R)} (B.10.41) and that g = g . Proof. The proof of this is very similar to all the other proofs in this section. We will go over the highlights. We want to define an AL() and a U,L D,L satisfying Ad(AL()) U,L D,L() = 0H;L H;01(L) (B.10.42) and similarly for the right side. We will only work out this side as the other calculation is analogous. We do this in two steps. First we find an interaction satisfying 0; = 0H;L H;01(L). We can do this by taking the usual (Z, t) := X(m)(0H;t1(L)(H(X, t))) m=0 XZ X(m)=Z 5Meaning that ()(A) is continuous for all A A. (B.10.43) (B.10.44) OPERATORS BELONGING TO 0H;1 where H := HL H1(L). We can now define L() := 0;W(C)cL. (B.10.45) This means that we can satisfy B.10.41 if Ad(AL) = 0; ;0 := W(C)cUL + W(C)cDL. (B.10.46) Using the same argument as before, this can be realised when we have Ad(AL()) = 0; (B.10.47) where (Z, t) := X(m)(0;t((X, t) (X, t))). (B.10.48) m=0 XZ X(m)=ZThe last part of the proof is to show that Z BZ2 (Z, t) < which can be done using similar techniques as before. This means that we can simply define AL() := T expi ds (Z, s) (B.10.49) 0 ZB 2 Z and this is by construction bounded and continuous in . B.11 Operators belonging to 0H;1 We will complete the proof of theorem 5.4.26. Lemma B.11.1. The following operators now belong to 0H;1 : = 0(A1)v0(A1) (B.11.1) Wg = 0(A1)1(gL gR)2(Wg)0(A1) (B.11.2) (g, h) = 0(A1)1(gWghWgu(g, h)(gh))0(A1) (B.11.3) Kg = 0(A1)1(vgvKg(g))0(A1 ) (B.11.4) where g = 0 0 0H;1 (A2,g ) with A2,g defined in 5.4.115 and A1 was defined in equation (5.4.113). Proving that (g, h) and Kg are operators belonging to 0H;1 is completely analogous. This concludes the proof. We will now finish the proof of theorem 5.5.27. OPERATORS BELONGING TO 0H;1 Lemma B.11.2.
